response: For a cross-listed course at the University of South Carolina, such as FAMS 598 - Special Topics in Global Film and Media, there are specific requirements that must be met. First, students should have completed FAMS 240 as a prerequisite. This course can also be cross-listed with FORL 598 or MART 594, depending on the topic. Make sure to check the course description for any additional requirements or stipulations, as they may vary by title.
reference: “A cross-listed course is a course that is offered under more than one course subject and is not appropriate for courses with the same course subject. Once a cross-listed course is approved,the courses are viewed as equivalent and identical and should ideally be able to be taken interchangeably within degree programs which require the course.” (ACAF 2.03) Cross-listed courses must have the exact same criteria as listed below: Course Number (if possible; at minimum the course numbers for the cross-listed courses must have be at the same level,i.e.,lower division,upper division,mixed,graduate) Title Course Description Pre-requisites and Co-requisites Catalog Restrictions (e.g.,by student level or program) Carolina Core or GLD designations (if applicable) Grade Mode (i.e.,letter grade or pass/fail) Schedule Type (e.g.,lecture,lab,seminar) a. Cross-listed courses may have different course delivery and location.

user_input: What are the requirements for a syllabus?
retrieved_contexts: ['structures. A primary purpose of a syllabus is to communicate to your students what the course is about, why it is taught, where it is going, and what will be required for them to complete the course with a passing grade. Because students will view your syllabus as a kind of "contract," it is important to be as clear as possible, and to avoid changing major aspects of the syllabus after the first day of class. View Steps to a Good Syllabus,(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/good_syllabus_steps/index.php) Syllabus Best Practices,(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/templates/summer_2021/cte_syllabus_best_practices.pdf) and Syllabus Templates(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/index.php) on the Center for Teaching Excellence’s website for additional information on creating a quality syllabus. The syllabus clearly outlines academic integrity expectations. Safeguarding academic integrity in the online environment is essential. It is important to minimize the potential for academic integrity violations. Your syllabus should clearly outline academic integrity expectations. Below are some suggestions: The design of assessments should minimize opportunities for academic integrity violations (e.g., by use of date/time restrictions, randomized questions, Respondus Lockdown Browser or Respondus Monitor for timed tests, ProctorU, SafeAssign for graded written work). Include a clear policy on acceptable use of social media as it relates to course content. Create a clear policy on the dissemination of course materials and assignments external to the course environment. Include course requirements for students to demonstrate understanding of Academic Integrity expectations (e.g., complete an academic integrity quiz, sign an Honor Code agreement, etc.) Highlight the need for students to report academic integrity violations that are not their own to avoid complicity. Include specific penalties for not adhering to academic integrity expectations. Additional Resources Student Conduct and Academic Integrity(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student_conduct_and_academic_integrity/index.php) Grading and Testing Online Distributed Learning: Exams and Testing(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/distributed_learning/examsandtesting/index.php) Online Assessment', 'outcome? If course content potentially overlaps with content offered by another program, has a letter of concurrence been provided? Policy Statements Does the syllabus include a suitable statement regarding academic integrity? Does the syllabus include a suitable statement regarding attendance policy? Does the syllabus include a suitable statement regarding students with disabilities? Evaluation Does this syllabus specify assignments, projects, quizzes, and/or exams with brief descriptions of expectations and points/weights assigned to each activity? Does the syllabus clearly indicate the grading scale, weight of each assignment (points or percentage), and how grades will be assigned? If standard grades are used, does the syllabus indicate how letters A-F will be assigned (by points or percentage)? (Note: the grades of B+, C+, D+, and F+ are permitted but A+ and "minus" grades are not.) If pass/fail grades are an option does the syllabus indicate the minimum grade (points, percentage) required for a "pass"? 500/600 level course? If this is 500/600 level course: Does the syllabus indicate separate grading scheme for graduate students? Does the syllabus include one or more requirements for graduate credit that are clearly differentiated from undergraduate assignments? Graduate work is normally evaluated on a more rigorous basis than that of undergraduate work. Does the syllabus provide different grading criteria for graduate students (typically based on distinct assignment) equivalent to one letter grade if not done (e.g., student cannot earn an A if not completed)? Course Outline/Schedule and Materials (All Courses) Does the syllabus include a citation for required reading/material? Does the syllabus include information about how to access any third-party software or tools that may be required? Does the syllabus include a statement of compliance with copyright polices, e.g., "All readings/materials comply with copyright/fair use policies"? Does the syllabus include an appropriate module-by-module or unit-by-unit schedule for course topics and activities? Course Outline/Schedule and Materials (If >50% Online) Does the syllabus include a statement such as "All learning outcomes in this Distributed Learning course are equivalent to face-to-face', 'Steps to a Good Syllabus - Center for Teaching Excellence | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Center for Teaching Excellence SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Center for Teaching Excellence Teaching Resources Syllabus Templates Steps to a Good Syllabus Steps to a Good Syllabus Because students will view the syllabus as a kind of "contract," it is important to be as clear as possible, and to avoid changing major aspects of the syllabus after the first day of class. In deciding what to include in the syllabus, first include all information that students need to have at the beginning of the course. Second, include all information that students need to have in writing. There is no hard-and-fast rule about the proper length for a syllabus. If in doubt, it is usually best to err on the long side, to ensure that important course information is fully covered. At the same time, students will appreciate having key information in succinct form on the first page. Expand all 1. Get Started Before you start writing your syllabus, think first and foremost about the knowledge and skills students should gain in your course, then about how you will assess these knowledge and skills, and finally about the best ways for the students to learn them. Focusing on learning outcomes, rather than a list of topics to cover, generally results in a more satisfying course for you and your students. Organize the syllabus logically, and use consistent (underlined or bold-faced headings) to help students find information. We recommended that the syllabus be created in three main parts: (1) Course Description, (2) Course Outline, and (3) Policies and Procedures. Creating each of these parts separately gives you a set of three documents that can be easily adapted or directly reused for other courses taught 2. The Course Overview Section The course description components of the syllabus should not be changed during the running of the course. A well constructed one or two page document is usually sufficient to include the following: The', '- Syllabus Construction Guide SP 7.00 - Syllabus Suggestions SP 8.00 - Academic Integrity SP 9.00 - Faculty Guide to Student Hiring Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.']
response: A syllabus should include a clear and detailed course description, including learning objectives, expectations for academic integrity, attendance policy, accommodations for students with disabilities, evaluation methods, grading scale, and a course outline or schedule with brief descriptions of each topic or activity. It should also specify assignment requirements and weights, and include statements regarding the distribution of course materials and acceptable use of social media. Additionally, it's important to minimize opportunities for academic integrity violations through assessment design and to have a clear policy on reporting violations and assigning penalties. The syllabus should be written in a logical and consistent format with headings for easy navigation.
reference: All undergraduate and graduate courses must have a course syllabus that includes the following: Course title (including course subject designator and number) Instructor name and relevant contact information Final Exam day and time,as appropriate (from Office of the Registrar’s website) Class meeting days,times,and location,or equivalent Undergraduate or Graduate Bulletin course description Course learning outcomes Required text(s) and/or suggested readings,as appropriate Course requirements and grading Assignments,projects,quizzes,and/or exams with brief descriptions of expectations with points/weights assigned to each activity. Courses at the Mixed/Advanced Undergraduate/Entry Level Graduate Courses (500/600--level) must include separate grading schemes for undergraduate and graduate credit and one or more assignments for graduate credit that are clearly differentiated from undergraduate assignments Grading scheme and weights including what a student must do to receive a grade of A through F for a letter grade-based course,or an S or U,or a T or U,as appropriate for a non-letter grade course Topical outline of content to be covered,including a time allocation framework (e.g.,week 1,week 2,etc. to include 14 weeks for a standard academic year course 6 session). The time allocation framework will be adjusted for other term lengths accordingly,consistent with course credit hours as defined in section III D. For Distributed Learning Courses,the syllabus is expected to articulate estimated time commitments of instructional time and course activity time consistent with course credit hours as defined above. The Committee on Instructional Development shall maintain and administer guidelines for such courses. Statement regarding academic integrity,honorable behavior and/or the Carolinian Creed (or excerpt thereof). Additional information may be found through the Office of Academic Integrity . Sample syllabi are also available through the Center for Teaching Excellence. Course attendance policy consistent with the expectations stated in the respective Academic Bulletin. Statement regarding disability services. Additional information may be found through the Student Disability Services Center and in policy STAF 6.02 Support Services and Accommodations for Students with Diagnosed Disabilities. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student_conduct_and_academic_integrity/,/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/,/about/offices_and_divisions/student_disability_resource_center/for_faculty_and_staff/classroom_accessibility/index.php)

user_input: What is a concentration?
retrieved_contexts: ["Data Dictionary - Office of Institutional Research, Assessment, and Analytics | University of South Carolina VARIABLE NAME: First_Concentration DESCRIPTOR: First Concentration DEFINITION: Used for identifying a student's first concentration within the degree program that totals at least 18 credit hours of coursework. Unlike a minor, a first concentration requires CHE approval. First Concentrations that total less than 18 hours of coursework do not require CHE approval and are not carried on the students' records. VALUES: See the Concentration Codes(http://ipr.sc.edu/xls/banner/major.xlsx) spreadsheet. FIELD ATTRIBUTE: A4 SOURCE: USC Enrollment and Degrees Awarded Files EXAMPLE: To select students with an area of emphasis in Japanese within the Professional Masters of Business program, type First_Concentration='M855' in the WHERE statement.", 'Concentration in Performance - Department of Theatre and Dance | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Department of Theatre and Dance SC.edu Study Colleges and Schools Arts and Sciences Department of Theatre and Dance Theatre Degrees Offered B.A. Concentration in Performance Concentration in Performance Preparation for a Life On Stage, Screen and Beyond The B.A. in Theatre with Concentration in Performance is a specialized program of study that provides solid preparation for the professionally-focused undergraduate actor who wants to develop their talent to confidently enter the professional arena and/or continue their education in a graduate training program. A carefully constructed sequence of courses will assist actors in developing their technique, creativity, collaborative skills, and artistic vision. The Concentration in Performance offers a wealth of opportunity for theatre majors to gain acting experience in a wide range of genres while undertaking in-depth training in the actor’s craft. This special concentration will appear on your official transcript. Features of the Performance Concentration Roles in Our Production Program Our theatre program produces several mainstage productions per year, as well as laboratory productions in our black box theatre and student-directed works produced by our independent student ensemble. Students will have the opportunity to audition for all productions and collaborate with MFA Acting students. In-Depth Training Studio classes include: • fundamentals of acting onstage and for the camera; • voice; • movement; • physical acting and ensemble devising; • advanced courses in scene study, film acting, and heightened text and style. Faculty Mentorship Each student works with a faculty advisor throughout their course of study for regular assessments and post-graduate planning and advice. Major Map(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/documents/major_maps/2023-2024/2023_thea-performance_map.pdf) Click the heading above to explore a sample Performance Concentration program of study. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.']
response: A concentration is a specific field or area of focus within a degree program, typically requiring at least 18 credit hours of coursework. At the University of South Carolina, concentrations must be approved by the Committee for Higher Education (CHE). For example, a student majoring in Theatre could choose a Concentration in Performance, which will appear on their official transcript and offer opportunities for acting experience in various genres and in-depth training in the actor's craft.
reference: "A Concentration is a series of courses that display a distinct curricular pattern within the major. They are often called options,emphases,tracks,areas,fields,or specializations. These are different from minors or cognates which are typically outside of the major. Concentrations are subject to faculty governance review,and appear on the transcripts but not the diplomas." (ACAF 2.00)

user_input: What is an integrative course?
retrieved_contexts: ['program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns. Carolina Core Courses Designating a foundational course as Carolina Core Designating a course as Carolina Core requires approval by the Carolina Core Committee. For a new course submitted in APPS, complete the Carolina Core information. If adding the Carolina Core designation to an existing course, a course change proposal must be submitted in APPS with the Carolina Core information completed. Integrative Course Proposals An Integrative course is an upper division course that includes one or more learning outcomes from the Carolina Core. The purpose of this course is to ensure that learning outcomes from the Core are integrated into higher level classes in the major. This process is based on the original intent of integrative courses from the 10-06-2010 Faculty Senate meeting which gave individual academic programs the leeway to design these courses as they see fit. The intent of these courses is to facilitate awareness and attention to some of the Core foundational skills or knowledge being threaded up through the curriculum. As a result, regulatory oversight is ceded predominantly to the academic unit. A department must identify one or more upper-level major courses that incorporates one or more of the Carolina Core learning outcomes such that every student in that major will take at least one integrative course. The following is the process to designate or delete an Integrative course. Add an Integrative Course Submit a new course proposal or course change proposal as appropriate in APPS. In the justification section, provide the following information: Carolina Core Integrative Course, Major Name, Degree (e.g., ANTH 444, Anthropology, B.S.) and explain which Carolina Core Learning outcomes(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/academicpriorities/undergradstudies/carolinacore/faculty-and-staff/learning-outcomes.php) are met by the course and how the course', 'About the Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning - Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning SC.edu About Initiatives and Special Programs Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning About About the Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning The Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning (CIEL), formerly USC Connect, leads the University of South Carolina’s comprehensive initiative to enhance undergraduate education and build a culture of integrative learning. Integrative learning at USC is about making connections across within and beyond the classroom experiences and includes student engagement in community service, research, peer leadership, internships, and study abroad. Integrative learning is more than just having the experience though and also includes learning from the experience and connecting learning to academic study. The final step is applying learning to solve problems and make decisions . . . applying learning to lead. USC students’ educational experiences are enriched by engagement within and beyond the classroom and their ability to connect these experiences is the heart of a truly meaningful education. CIEL promotes student opportunities to engage beyond the classroom and synthesize and apply learning across experiences. Graduation with Leadership Distinction is the Center’s signature program and recognizes students for significant engagement and learning, including leadership through solution-oriented thinking. Experiential Learning is also encouraged for all undergraduate students. Mission To advance integrative and experiential learning across within and beyond the classroom experiences at the University of South Carolina Columbia and Palmetto College campuses for students, faculty, and staff by providing programs, developing resources, conducting outreach, and facilitating assessment. Vision To foster an enriched educational environment through purposeful within and beyond the classroom experiences that deepen the impact on student learning and enhance their preparation for the future. National Presence CIEL, formerly USC Connect, was highlighted in The Undergraduate Experience: Focusing Institutions on What Matters Most(https://www.amazon.com/Undergraduate-Experience-Focusing-Institutions-Matters/dp/111905074X/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1536262181&sr=8-1&keywords=the+undergraduate+experience+focusing+institutions+on+what+matters) in 2016 as an example of intentional alignment in higher education across educational purpose, student needs, resources, policies, and practices. Details on aspects of our programs published in 2018 include: Integrative Learning and Graduation with Leadership Distinction: ePortfolios and Institutional Change. In Catalyst in Action: Case Studies of High Impact ePortfolio Practice(https://www.amazon.com/Catalyst-Action-High-Impact-ePortfolio-Practice/dp/1620368676/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1536265268&sr=8-1&keywords=catalyst+in+action) (Eynon & Gambino). Game Changer: How a Graduation Distinction Can Impact Learning for All [pdf] , eSource for College Transitions, National Resource Center. Closing the Feedback Loop: Visible Learning with Intentional Reflection [pdf] ,Synergy, NASPA Student Affairs Partnering with Academic Affairs Knowledge Community. View a more complete list [pdf] of recent publications and presentations by CIEL and our faculty and staff partners. Our Administration CIEL is housed in the Office of the Provost and overseen by the vice provost and dean of undergraduate studies. Office staff includes a faculty executive director, an associate director for assessment and director of the quality enhancement plan, an assistant director for student services, and student advisors/consultants. Faculty fellows serve as advocates for integrative learning and provide faculty perspectives to the Center. The CIEL Council , composed of administrators, faculty, and student representatives, provides global direction and oversight. The Student Advisory Council provides ongoing feedback. CIEL partners with all colleges/schools and many offices throughout the university. Awards 2016 Go Abroad Innovation Award Recognizing pioneering universities who offer productive re-entry programming to study abroad participants. 2016 NASPA Excellence Award Recognizing the impact USC Connect has on student learning, cross campus collaboration, originality, and sustainability. 2014 AGLS Exemplary Program Award Recognizing innovative efforts using co-curricular activities to accomplish the goals of general education. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', "Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning - USC Sumter | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning At the University of South Carolina, what you learn inside the classroom is only the beginning. Part of the USC Family As a USC Sumter student, you’re a member of the University of South Carolina family and can take advantage of programs like the Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning(http://www.sc.edu/about/initiatives/usc_connect/index.php) . True learning extends beyond the classroom. That means taking what you've learned and connecting it to your own personal experiences. In order to truly distinguish yourself, we encourage you to think about the experiences that you'd like to gain during your time at the university. Now stop and think again. This time dig deeper, and think about how those experiences can influence your academics, how your academics can enhance your experiences and how both can impact your long-term goals. This interweaving of learning inside and beyond the classroom is called integrative learning and at South Carolina we call it the Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning . Your Experience By following the steps of the Center for Integrative and Experiential Learning , you can create your plan(http://www.sc.edu/about/initiatives/usc_connect/create_your_plan/index.php) so that your experiences can be applied in a purposeful way. Our partners—faculty and staff across the university—can show you how to choose your experiences, engage in the ones that are right for you, reflect on what you've learned and then share what you've learned(http://www.sc.edu/about/initiatives/usc_connect/share_what_you_learn/index.php) with others to demonstrate your leadership skills. The pathways of experience that you choose can lead you to pursue special recognition through Graduation with Leadership Distinction(http://www.sc.edu/about/initiatives/usc_connect/graduation_with_leadership_distinction/index.php) and ultimately prepare you for life and success beyond USC. Don’t miss your chance to participate in theCenter for Integrative and Experiential Learning.(http://www.sc.edu/about/initiatives/usc_connect/index.php) USC Sumter Campus Visit There's no better way to learn about USC Sumter than to schedule a campus visit! We look forward to showing you everything we have to offer. response:
An integrative course is an upper division course that includes one or more learning outcomes from the Carolina Core. These courses aim to ensure that learning outcomes from the Core are integrated into higher level classes in the major. The purpose of integrative courses is to facilitate awareness and attention to some of the Core foundational skills or knowledge being threaded up through the curriculum. Regulatory oversight for integrative courses is ceded predominantly to the academic unit, meaning each department must identify one or more upper-level major courses that incorporate one or more of the Carolina Core learning outcomes.

To add the Carolina Core designation to an existing course or submit a new course proposal with the Carolina Core information completed, use the APPS system. If you need assistance, follow the instructions provided on the Carolina Core website: https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/academicpriorities/undergradstudies/carolinacore/faculty-and-staff/learning-outcomes.php
reference: An Integrative course is a course in the major,in which selected Carolina Core learning outcomes are integrated into the chosen major. Each undergraduate program must have an approved integrative course and require it as part of the major to ensure that all undergraduate students have had an integrative course in their major. It cannot just be an option in the major. Learn more on integrative courses . (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/academicpriorities/undergradstudies/carolinacore/courses/integrative-courses.php)

user_input: What is DegreeWorks?
retrieved_contexts: ['a two-way student communication platform optimized for mobile viewing; more coordinated case management across the university; and dashboards to highlight key student success metrics and resource utilization. Pathfinder will be implemented over a two year period and will replace SARS for scheduling with more robust functionality. DegreeWorks DegreeWorks aids both students and advisors in monitoring students’ progress toward degree and assist students in choosing the most appropriate courses to fulfill degree requirements. Integrated with students’ academic records in Banner, DegreeWorks matches student record data (courses, hours grades) with degree requirements categorically to identify which courses meet degree requirements and which courses need to be completed. Degree works also allows users to run “what if” and “look ahead” scenarios to both show how project courses will apply to a student’s major and apply a student’s course history to another program of study. Cognos Datawarehouse The Data Warehouse is a repository of generated reports from student, financial, and human resource systems. Authorized student support staff can view, access, and print reports for administrative purposes. Internet Native Banner (INB) Internet Native Banner is the student information system at the University of South Carolina. It is primarily used by core administrative offices including the offices of admissions, registrar, financial aid, and bursar to view and maintain data and process transactions. How to Obtain Access For new access requests to student systems, take the following steps: Academic & Faculty Advisors, Academic Services Staff in Colleges Visit the Advising Technology Access(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/advisor_toolbox/advising_technology/index.php) webpage for detailed instructions. Teaching Faculty For SSC access: Please consult with your college/department schedule coordinator . For Other Student Systems: Please work']
response: DegreeWorks is an online tool that helps students and their advisors monitor students' progress towards degree completion. It matches student record data, such as courses and grades, with degree requirements to identify which courses meet those requirements and which ones still need to be completed. This tool also enables users to explore "what if" and "look ahead" scenarios, showing how prospective courses will apply to a student's major and applying a student's course history to another program of study. DegreeWorks is integrated with students' academic records in Banner and assists both students and advisors in selecting the most appropriate courses to fulfill degree requirements.
reference: DegreeWorks is the University’s degree audit system. DegreeWorks aids both students and advisors in monitoring students’ progress toward degree and assist students in choosing the most appropriate courses to fulfill degree requirements. Integrated with students’ academic records in Banner,DegreeWorks matches student record data (courses,hours grades) with degree requirements categorically to identify which courses meet degree requirements and which courses need to be completed. Degree works also allows users to run “what if” and “look ahead” scenarios to both show how project courses will apply to a student’s major and apply a student’s course history to another program of study. ( Office of the University Registrar ) Learn more with the DegreeWorks Overview training module. (/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/toolbox/sysaccess/index.php,https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=syUFK9gy56g&feature=youtu.be)

user_input: What is EAB Navigate?
retrieved_contexts: ['EAB Navigate - Academic Advising | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Academic Advising SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Academic Advising Advisor Toolbox Advising Technology Pathfinder EAB Navigate EAB Navigate is an advising software that serves as a resource for advisors containing student information, notes, success markers, progression, and incorporates appointment scheduling. What is Navigate? EAB Navigate is one of the four advising technologies used on the USC Columbia campus. It is heavily utilized as the primary scheduling platform for academic advising appointments, as well as for nearly two dozen student service offices around campus. The original platform is intended to guide the prioritization of outreach to and interaction with students based on risk levels and success marker flags. The success markers are established by each department based on the courses that are most predictive of success in each major over time using USC historic student data, or based on critical courses from major maps. These involve both threshold grades in key courses and the timing of those courses. Risk levels are based on student performance and characteristics relative to other students who have graduated in the particular major. Success markers, risk levels, and student characteristics (GPA ranges, class level, department, college, native/transfer, etc.) can be used to quickly query lists of students who may need further assistance. EAB Navigate for Scheduling - Academic Units The list below includes all colleges, departments, and advising units currently utilizing EAB Navigate for scheduling their appointments with students. The column for EAB: Scheduling indicates the method the department/college is using to meet with students, whereas the EAB: Advisor Notes column indicates if the advisors are uploading or recording notes in the software. Partial indicates more than 50% of advisors at that location are recording notes in EAB Navigate. Login with your USC ID number and password (same username and password you use for Self-Service Carolina and USC email). With Navigate360 You Can: Expand all Stay Organized It keeps all your tasks in one place, providing a customized list of deadlines and events to create a timeline for your success. Schedule Appointments You can make appointments for success consultations, tutoring, leadership and service coaching, advising, and much more all from your phone. Access Your Class Schedule You can view your class schedule to access your semester’s courses and their locations by clicking on the campus building link to USC’s maps. View your Success Team You can view a list of your instructors, advisor, Carolina Experience Peer Leader and Career Coach. You only see information for staff assigned to you. To-dos & Events: Upcoming tasks or key dates that are either mandatory, to be completed in the future, or optional. Students can add their own reminders. Resources: List of key people and places on campus; key people include a students’ professors, advisors, and their basic contact information while key places include contact information, descriptions, and a link to get directions. Class Schedule: Both a list and schedule view of courses that a student is currently registered for. List view includes additional details about location and instructor while schedule view is a visual representation of a given week of classes. Appointment Center: Students can see upcoming appointments, appointment requests, and make an appointment with their advisors, tutors, and other various staff members on campus. Staff will see these appointments on their Navigate staff platform. Study Buddies: Students can opt in to “Study Buddies” for any course they are currently enrolled in. Opting in will provide email contact information for other students who have also opted in, providing students with a simple way to contact and study with peers. Hold Center: Students can see their active holds (updated nightly) and how to resolve them. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', 'Navigate for Faculty and Staff - Carolina Experience | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Carolina Experience SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Carolina Experience About Us Navigate360 For Faculty and Staff Navigate for Faculty and Staff Use Navigate360 to meet with students, record notes from student appointments, send students a post-appointment survey, create an appointment campaign, and much more. Faculty and Staff Login(https://sc.campus.eab.com/login?prevent_redirect=true) With Navigate360 You Can: Expand all Stay Organized Staff can set up availability in Navigate360 so that students can schedule an appointment for services that your office offers. Connect with Students Utilize the communications feature within Navigate360 to view your direct correspondence with students that was sent through the platform. Create and Send Appointment Campaigns Use this tool to reach out to specific student populations by sending them a request to schedule an appointment, set a deadline with a “schedule by” date, and view at-a-glance who has not scheduled an appointment. View a Student’s Success Team Faculty and staff can view the Success Team for their students on the bottom right section of the student profile page. This information can be helpful when you need to connect and contact a member of a student’s success team. Complete Progress Reports If you receive an email from a USC staff member regarding a progress report for your class, please promptly complete in order for students to receive the best resources for their needs. When you submit a progress report, a USC staff member will contact your student and provide customized support based on the at-risk alert reason. Submit an Alert Through the Navigate360 platform, faculty, instructors, and campus partners can submit alerts on behalf of students for academic and/or financial support at any time. In addition to alerts, staff can submit kudos for students who are excelling in class, have improved their performance, and/or positively contributed to class through participation/engagement. Share your idea.(https://universityofsouthcarolina-yrckc.formstack.com/forms/navigate360_event_to_do_and_tips_idea_submission) Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.']
response: EAB Navigate is an advising software that serves as a resource for advisors containing student information, notes, success markers, progression, and incorporates appointment scheduling. It is one of the four advising technologies used on the USC Columbia campus, primarily for scheduling academic advising appointments and interacting with students based on risk levels and success markers. Advisors can use it to guide prioritization of outreach to students and record notes in the software. EAB Navigate for Students allows users to stay organized, schedule appointments, access their class schedule, view their success team, and explore features in the app.
reference: The EAB Advising Platform (known as Navigate on the Columbia campus),populated by a nightly feed of student data from Banner,provides a simple overview of key student information; success marker notifications; risk scoring for early intervention; a full transcript view and incoming student test and placement scores; easy list development based on hundreds of student attributes (GPA ranges; credit completion percentages; specific courses; participation in certain groups such as Honors,athletics,or sorority/fraternity; transfers; etc); a major matcher feature integrated with hiring and salary data provided by O-Net; easy referrals to support offices across campus who will reach out to the student and then close the loop with the advisor who made the referral. Learn more with the EAB Navigate Overview training module. (/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/advisor_toolbox/advising_technology/navigate/index.php,https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MTYWVP8Dp5A&feature=youtu.be)

response:
Progression requirements typically refer to the conditions or standards that students need to meet in order to advance in their academic programs. From the provided context, there are different examples of progression requirements mentioned for various programs at the University of South Carolina (USC). Here are some key components found in these requirements:

1. **Minimum GPA**: Students must maintain a certain Grade Point Average (GPA) in their overall studies as well as specific subjects. For instance, achieving an Overall GPA of 2.75 or higher and a GPA of 3.0 or higher in Education courses is necessary for Early Childhood Education students.

2. **Specific course completion**: Completion of certain courses with specific grades is essential before moving forward. An example includes completing ENGL 101 and ENGL 102 with a grade of 'C' or better for most programs.

3. **Prerequisites**: Some courses may require successful completion of other courses as prerequisites. For example, specific science and math courses might need to be finished before taking upper-level classes.

4. **Assessments and examinations**: Passing certain assessments or examinations may be mandatory. For instance, the EEDA assessment is a requirement for Early Childhood Education Professional Program admission.

5. **Deadlines**: Meeting deadlines for submitting scores or applications, like submitting Praxis Core and EEDA requirements by December 1st prior to entering junior spring block courses in the Early Childhood Education program.

Remember that each program has its unique set of progression requirements, so it's important to check the specific guidelines for the chosen area of study.
reference: Progression requirements should inform students and advisors of any deadlines and minimum performance standards to continue in a program. They may include deadlines for course or application completion,minimum GPA requirements,minimum grade requirements,minimum number of credits earned,etc. Learn more with the Progression Requirements training module. retrieved_contexts: ['Carolina Core Assessment Schedules - Institutional Research, Assessment, and Analytics | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Institutional Research, Assessment, and Analytics SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Institutional Research, Assessment, and Analytics Assessment Carolina Core Assessment Resources Carolina Core Assessment Schedules Carolina Core Assessment Schedules Yearly Calendar by Department (PDF) (Columbia and Palmetto College Campuses) Term by Department and Section - Fall 2024 Columbia (PDF) Palmetto College (PDF) Term by Department and Section - Spring 2024 Columbia (PDF) Palmetto College (PDF) Challenge the conventional. No Limits.', 'What Makes up my Program of Study? - My Arts and Sciences | University of South Carolina Skip to Content My Arts and Sciences SC.edu Study Colleges and Schools My Arts and Sciences Undergraduate Students Advising For Students What Makes up my Program of Study? What Makes up my Program of Study? In the College of Arts and Sciences, your program of study consists of the following requirements: Carolina Core, College Requirements, Electives, Program courses, Major courses, and either a Minor or Cognate. CAS programs require between 120 to 128 credit hours to graduate, depending upon your major. Learn more about the requirements below. Carolina Core The Carolina Core(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/academicpriorities/undergradstudies/carolinacore/) is a set of requirements that students across the University of South Carolina have to complete as part of their program of study. The Carolina Core is made up of 10 core components, each with a learning outcome and credit hour requirements. Click below on each requirement to learn more. You can find the entire list of Carolina Core applicable courses, as well as the requirements that they fulfill in the most recent academic bulletin(https://academicbulletins.sc.edu/undergraduate/carolina-core-courses/#foundationalcoursestext) . College Requirements The College Requirements are different from the Carolina Core, in that they are only required for the specific college in which you are studying. While looking at the separate components of the Carolina Core above, you may have noticed that there is some overlap between Carolina Core and College Requirements for the College of Arts and Sciences. Click on each College Requirement below to learn more. For more information on the College Requirements, follow the link to the College of Arts and Sciences College Requirements on the academic bulletin(https://academicbulletins.sc.edu/undergraduate/arts-sciences/#text) . Expand all Additional Humanities Every student within the College of Arts and Sciences is required to take at least one additional Humanities class. Students who are pursuing a BS are only required to take 3 hours of additional Humanities, while students who are pursuing a BA are', 'Academic Programs < University of South Carolina 2024-2025 Academic Bulletin Menu 2024-2025 Edition Search bulletin Submit search Print Options Academic Programs On This Page Academic Programs Carolina Core Requirements Carolina Core Courses Other Requirements Special Academic Opportunities Cognates and Minors Graduation with Leadership Distinction South Carolina Honors College Study Abroad University 101 Undergraduate Research Service Learning Leadership Learning Career and Pre-Professional Counseling Teacher Preparation Academic Programs Undergraduate degree programs on the Columbia campus are offered through the Colleges of Arts and Sciences ; Hospitality, Retail, and Sport Management ; Education ; Molinaroli Engineering and Computing ; College of Information and Communications ; Nursing ; Pharmacy ; and Social Work and through the School of Music , the Arnold School of Public Health , and the Darla Moore School of Business . For a list of undergraduate programs offered on the Columbia Campus visit the following link: Programs A-Z Carolina Core Requirements The Carolina Core curriculum provides the common core of knowledge, skill, and academic experience for all Carolina undergraduates. It has 10 Core components, each with learning outcomes and credit hour requirements. The Core begins with foundational courses early in the undergraduate experience, followed by one or more integrative courses near the end in which selected Core learning outcomes are integrated into the chosen major. Each of the ten Core components must be met with a Core-approved course. While most Core-approved courses fulfill a single Core component, a few courses, called overlay-eligible courses, have been approved to fulfill two Core components. Every student is required to complete a minimum of 31 credit hours of Core-approved courses. Transfer students who enter USC Columbia, Lancaster, Salkehatchie, Sumter, or Union are subject to the Carolina Core requirements. Any transfer courses that equate to Carolina Core courses will equate to both content and all outcomes associated with the USC Course. Visit the Carolina Core website( http://www.sc.edu/generaleducation/) for more information. Carolina Core Requirements Code Carolina Core Components Carolina Core Learning Outcomes Credit Hours I. Lower Division: Core Courses Learning Outcomes to be met at foundational level of mastery 31-43 hours CMW Effective, Engaged, and Persuasive Communication: Written Component Identify and analyze issues, develop logical and persuasive arguments, and communicate ideas clearly for a variety of audiences and purposes through writing and speaking. 6 Written component ARP Analytical Reasoning and Problem-Solving Apply the methods of mathematical, statistical, or analytical reasoning to critically evaluate data, solve problems, and effectively communicate findings verbally and graphically. 6 SCI Scientific Literacy Apply the principles and language of the natural sciences and associated technologies to historical and contemporary issues. 7 GFL Global Citizenship and Multicultural Understanding: Foreign Language Communicate effectively in more than one language. 0-6 (depending on placement test) GHS Global Citizenship and Multicultural Understanding: Historical Thinking Use the principles of historical thinking to understand past human societies. 3 GSS Global Citizenship and Multicultural Understanding: Social Sciences Use the principles of the social sciences to explore diverse cultural identities and to analyze political and environmental issues. 3 AIU Aesthetic and Interpretive Understanding Create or interpret literary, visual or performing arts 3 II. Lower Division: Stand-Alone or Overlay-Eligible Courses Up to two of these three Core requirements may be met in overlay courses that combine learning outcomes from two Core courses. 3-9 hours (depending on whether these three outcomes are met with stand-alone or up to two overlay courses) CMS Effective, Engaged, and Persuasive Communication: Spoken Component Identify and analyze issues, develop logical and persuasive arguments, and communicate ideas clearly for a variety of audiences and purposes through writing and speaking. 0-3 Spoken component INF Information Literacy Collect, manage and evaluate information using technology, and communicate findings. 0-3 VSR Values, Ethics, and Social Responsibility Examine different kinds of social and personal values, analyzing the ways in which these are manifested in communities as well as individual lives. 0-3 Integrative III. Upper Division: Integrative Course in the Major Upper division course in the major program of study includes learning outcomes from the Carolina Core. Students should refer to their program major for more information. N/A TOTAL Hours in Carolina Core 31-43 hours (depending on language placement tests and use of at most two overlay courses) Carolina Core Courses Foundational Courses Integrative Courses Other Requirements All undergraduate students must take a 3-credit course or its equivalent with a passing grade in the subject areas of History, Political Science, or African American Studies that covers the founding documents including the United State Constitution, the Declaration of Independence, the Emancipation Proclamation and one or more documents that are foundational to the African American Freedom struggle, and a minimum of five essays from the Federalist papers. This course may count as a requirement in any part of the', 'Centers, Cores & Institutes | MUSC Research Skip to content Research About Centers About Centers, Cores & Institutes Centers and Programs MUSC has numerous Research Centers and the South Carolina SmartState® Program Search for Centers Cores MUSC has a large number of research cores that are open to investigators both within and outside the institution. These provide expertise and state-of-the-art instrumentation to support innovative biomedical research, ranging from basic to translational. Search for Cores Institutes MUSC Institutes are located on the Charleston peninsula occupying more than 80 acres of the downtown medical district. Search for Institutes', 'Join the USC Research Core teams March 15 for second annual Research Core Fair - Office of the Vice President for Research | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Office of the Vice President for Research SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Office of the Vice President for Research News & Publications Research News 2024 News Join the USC Research Core teams March 15 for second annual Research Core Fair Join the USC Research Core teams March 15 for second annual Research Core Fair Posted on: February 22, 2024; Updated on: January 9, 2024 The University of South Carolina is hosting a Research Core Fair on Friday, March 15, 2024, to spotlight the wealth of resources at the University that are available to researchers. Research cores at the University of South Carolina are shared research resources that provide access to equipment, instruments, technology and expert technical advice that researchers from any part of the University can use for a fee. The Research Core Fair is open to all USC students, faculty and staff. There will be four sessions featuring short talks which will detail capabilities of cores in the following areas: life sciences, chemistry, engineering and aerospace and earth, ocean and environment. There will also be tables or posters for each Research Core, posters by students and postdocs, and prizes for the best student posters. The Office of the Vice President for Research will provide lunch and refreshments during the breaks. All poster presenters get a $500 voucher at the Instrumentation Resource Facility and a $1000 Functional Genomics Core voucher for best poster presentation will be presented at the concluding reception. The Office of the Vice President for Research and research partners across the USC system look forward to highlighting the research tools available through the university. We encourage USC graduate and professional students, Principal Investigators, and those from other institutions who are interested in using the USC Research Cores to register(https://forms.office.com/pages/responsepage.aspx?id=GUsqSzXRDkKLsrHNI4mYzOcnzDMYXHpHp3ydldmUsQRURjFWWkhCWkY3VlBLNkU2S05WTzVXMlZCSS4u) for this event by March 8, 2024. Those who wish to present a poster at the event should submit their']
response: The Carolina Core is a set of requirements that students across the University of South Carolina have to complete as part of their program of study. It consists of 10 core components, each with a learning outcome and credit hour requirements. These components cover various aspects such as effective communication, analytical reasoning, scientific literacy, global citizenship, aesthetic understanding, and historical thinking.
reference: The Carolina Core provides the common core of knowledge,skill and academic experience for all Carolina undergraduate students. response:
An undergraduate degree program in Computer Science and Engineering at the University of South Carolina consists of foundational courses in mathematics, science, and computational subjects. It aims to prepare students for a professional career or further studies in computer science, computer engineering, and other fields. The department offers two undergraduate degrees: Computer Engineering (B.S.E.) and Computer Science (B.S.C.S.). Additionally, there is a Computer Information Systems (B.S.) degree available. Both the Computer Engineering and Computer Science degrees are accredited by the Engineering Accreditation Commission and Computing Accreditation Commission of ABET respectively.

The Computer Engineering program focuses on providing a strong foundation in hardware design, digital logic, computer architecture, systems programming, software engineering, and electives in various areas such as data analytics, machine learning, and security. On the other hand, the Computer Science program emphasizes algorithms, programming languages, software development, operating systems, artificial intelligence, databases, and electives in different domains like cybersecurity, computer graphics, and high-performance computing.

Furthermore, the University provides opportunities for minors in Computer Science, Applied Computing, and Data Science, along with a Cybersecurity: Information Assurance specialization. There is also a Bachelor's/Master's Accelerated Program that allows students to complete both bachelor's and master's degrees in less time.

user_input: What is the process for course actions?
retrieved_contexts: ['Course Actions - Office of the Provost | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Office of the Provost SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Office of the Provost Our Offices Academic Programs Course Actions Course Actions Course development consists of the creation of new courses and the revision or termination of existing courses. Revisions may include changes to the bulletin, delivery method, or other edits to be approved through faculty governance. Course Development Course development consists of creation and revision of curricula. The faculty of the University has legislative authority over matters pertaining to the curriculum on the campus where they serve. Faculty governance committees on each campus review all requests to create, revise, or eliminate graduate and undergraduate courses to ensure all offerings meet the academic expectation of the University. See ACAF 2.03 Creation and Revision of Academic Courses [pdf](http://sc.edu/policies/acaf203.pdf) Expand all New Course Propose a new course New courses require approval by the Unit Head, College/School Representative, Curricula and Courses and Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. Proposals for new courses are submitted in APPS. The C & C committee, Faculty Senate or Graduate Council may request program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns. Change a Course Propose a change to a course Changes to an existing course require approval by the Unit Head, Office of Distributed Learning (if adding DL delivery), College/School Representative, Carolina Core Committee (if change is to or adding a Carolina Core course) and Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. Changes may include hours, bulletin description, pre-requisites, etc. Proposals for course changes are submitted in APPS. The C & C committee, Faculty Senate or Graduate Council may request program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns. Terminate a Course Propose a course termination Course terminations require approval at Department, College Representative, Curricula and Courses/Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. Proposals for course termination are submitted in APPS. The C & C committee, Faculty Senate or Graduate Council may request program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns. Carolina Core Courses Designating a foundational course as Carolina']
response:
elements.

---

The process for course actions at the University of South Carolina involves several steps. To propose a new course, you need approval from the Unit Head, College/School Representative, Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. The proposal should be submitted through APPS, and the Curricula and Courses committee or Faculty Senate or Graduate Council might request program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns.

For changing an existing course, you also require approval from the Unit Head, Office of Distributed Learning (if adding DL delivery), College/School Representative, Carolina Core Committee (if changing to or adding a Carolina Core course), and Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. Changes may include various aspects like hours, bulletin description, or pre-requisites. Proposals for course changes are submitted in APPS, with possible program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns.

Lastly, terminating a course requires approval from the Department, College Representative, Curricula and Courses/Faculty Senate or Graduate Council. Proposals for course termination are submitted in APPS, with potential program representation at meetings to address questions or concerns. The Carolina Core Courses can be designated as foundational.

response: Cross-listed courses typically require additional proposals when they involve significant changes in course description, a change in Carolina Core or GLD designation, or a change in delivery mode to over 50% online. However, if the cross-listed courses only share the same course content and requirements between departments, a single proposal with letters of concurrence from both departments might suffice. It's essential to carefully review the context to determine if additional proposals or letters of concurrence are necessary.
reference: Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: Anytime a course is being deleted. If multiple cross-listed courses are being deleted,separate proposals are needed. Anytime a new course is being created. If a new course is to be cross listed with another new course,two proposals are needed (one for each course). If a new course is going to be cross listed with an existing course,only one proposal is needed. The proposal that creates the new course can also create the cross list,but does need a letter of concurrency. (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)

user_input: When is a syllabus required for a proposal?
retrieved_contexts: ['may be called for the purpose of an expedited vote when university due dates are incompatible with regularly scheduled Faculty Meetings. Faculty may approve the proposal in which case it will move forward to the appropriate Faculty Senate (undergraduate) or Graduate Council (graduate) committee. Faculty may also disapprove the proposal and refer it back to the initiator for revision. Proposal Components All proposals require a completed syllabus aligning with InDev requirements and all other university policy items (learning outcomes, required textbook, student support, disability, academic integrity, etc.) If the proposal is for a new permanent course, please contact the Chair of the Curriculum Committee for an appropriate new course number. Changes to courses must take into consideration any prerequisites/corequisites/cross listings, and other requirements of the course undergoing revision. Once the Curriculum Committee approves the proposal packet, the proposal will be forwarded for iSchool faculty approval. After the iSchool faculty approves the proposal, the proposal will be forwarded to the CIC Associate Dean for Academic Affairs for submission via the U of SC App system. O Expand all Office Assignments Date: 8/25/81; Revised: 10/4/16; 2/9/2024 POLICY When space becomes available the director shall determine if the space shall be used for faculty offices or some other purpose (research space, staff functions, etc.) based on the needs of the School. When appropriate, the Director will consult with faculty on space decisions. Upon determining that a space is to be used for faculty offices, the director shall offer it first to the most senior member of the faculty by rank and time on faculty. This process continues, working down the list of eligible faculty, until all spaces are assigned. Note that a change in rank or seniority', 'structures. A primary purpose of a syllabus is to communicate to your students what the course is about, why it is taught, where it is going, and what will be required for them to complete the course with a passing grade. Because students will view your syllabus as a kind of "contract," it is important to be as clear as possible, and to avoid changing major aspects of the syllabus after the first day of class. View Steps to a Good Syllabus,(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/good_syllabus_steps/index.php) Syllabus Best Practices,(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/templates/summer_2021/cte_syllabus_best_practices.pdf) and Syllabus Templates(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/cte/teaching_resources/syllabus_templates/index.php) on the Center for Teaching Excellence’s website for additional information on creating a quality syllabus. The syllabus clearly outlines academic integrity expectations. Safeguarding academic integrity in the online environment is essential. It is important to minimize the potential for academic integrity violations. Your syllabus should clearly outline academic integrity expectations. Below are some suggestions: The design of assessments should minimize opportunities for academic integrity violations (e.g., by use of date/time restrictions, randomized questions, Respondus Lockdown Browser or Respondus Monitor for timed tests, ProctorU, SafeAssign for graded written work). Include a clear policy on acceptable use of social media as it relates to course content. Create a clear policy on the dissemination of course materials and assignments external to the course environment. Include course requirements for students to demonstrate understanding of Academic Integrity expectations (e.g., complete an academic integrity quiz, sign an Honor Code agreement, etc.) Highlight the need for students to report academic integrity violations that are not their own to avoid complicity. Include specific penalties for not adhering to academic integrity expectations. Additional Resources Student Conduct and Academic Integrity(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student_conduct_and_academic_integrity/index.php) Grading and Testing Online Distributed Learning: Exams and Testing(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/distributed_learning/examsandtesting/index.php) Online Assessment']
response: A syllabus is required for a proposal when submitting a new course proposal or revising an existing course at the University of South Carolina. The syllabus should align with InDev requirements and all other university policies, including learning outcomes, required textbooks, student support, disability accommodations, and academic integrity expectations. For new permanent courses, please contact the Chair of the Curriculum Committee for an appropriate new course number. Any changes to courses must consider prerequisites, corequisites, and other requirements of the course undergoing revision. Once approved by the Curriculum Committee, the proposal will move forward for iSchool faculty approval, followed by the CIC Associate Dean for Academic Affairs for submission via the U of SC App system.
reference: Common Reasons Proposals are Returned from the Curricula and Courses Committee: A syllabus should only be included in a proposal when necessary. When a syllabus is included,it will be reviewed by the Committee on Curricula and Courses. Proposals that require a syllabus: New course Significant change in the course description,and/or title When required by other committees (i.e.,Carolina Core and Instructional Development -INDEV) Proposals that do not require a syllabus: Minor revisions to the course description or course title (e.g.,slight rephrasing to replace terms as dictated by professional organizations often related to accreditation) Change in co-requisites or pre-requisites Change in course level,as long as not changing to/from 500 or 600. Change in Catalog Restrictions Change in Carolina Core or GLD designations Change in Grade Mode (not needed for removing pass/fail; needed if adding pass/fail) Change in Schedule Type (e.g.,adding/changing lecture/lab/practicum format] Deleting a course (https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/provost/planning/academicprograms/docs/f23232.pdf)

user_input: When should I submit my proposal in order to be effective for the next Bulletin year?
retrieved_contexts: ["the following month. Materials received after the first of May or the first of December won't be reviewed until the start of the following semester. Track Your Submission You can check on the progress of your proposal through Academic Programs Proposal System (APPS) . It may take several days for a proposal to go through various levels of approval. Timeline Questions Contact Wanda Barr at (803) 777-1875 or wandab@mailbox.sc.edu . Review Process Curriculum committees review proposals i n the second week of each month. After the curriculum committee considers the proposal, the Graduate Council or the Faculty Senate (depending on the course level) will review. They will either approve the proposal or return it to the academic unit for revisions. Revisions If revisions are requested and made within the stated timeframe, the proposal will be sent out the Friday before the Graduate Council meeting that month. Final recommendations will be communicated by the chairs of the curriculum committees to the Graduate Council. Graduate Council Meetings of the Graduate Council are open, except for agenda items pertaining to personnel or student files. All faculty and staff are invited to attend. Date and Time Fourth Monday of each month during the academic year, except for December and May. December and May meetings are held on the second Monday. All meetings are at 2:00 p.m. Location Will be announced to department chairs and graduate directors and will be available on the Graduate School home page. Proposal Questions Contact Wanda Barr Phone: 803-777-1875 Email: wandab@mailbox.sc.edu Graduate Bulletin The Graduate Studies bulletin is the official document of record concerning graduate academic programs and regulations. Graduate Bulletin »(https://academicbulletins.sc.edu/graduate/) Graduate Program Director Manual The Graduate Program Director Manual provides a ready source of information concerning the policies of the Graduate School as stipulated by the Graduate Council and other University academic and administrative approval bodies. Graduate Program Director Manual(https://www.sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/graduate_school/documents/graduate_program_director_manual.pdf) Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits."]
response:
To ensure your proposal is effective for the next Bulletin year, materials should be submitted after the first of May or the first of December. However, keep in mind that these submissions won't be reviewed until the start of the following semester. You can track your submission's progress through the Academic Programs Proposal System (APPS), which may take several days due to various levels of approval.

Curriculum committees review proposals during the second week of each month. Afterward, the Graduate Council or the Faculty Senate will review the proposal depending on its level. They might approve it or request revisions. If revisions are made within the specified timeframe, the proposal will be sent out before the Graduate Council meeting that month, with final recommendations communicated by the curriculum committees' chairs. Graduate Council meetings are open, except for personnel or student files-related items. All faculty and staff are welcome to attend, usually on the fourth Monday of each month during the academic year, excluding December and May. In those months, meetings occur on the second Monday. Locations are announced to department chairs and graduate directors and are available on the Graduate School homepage.
reference: All proposals must reach the Committee on Curricula and Courses 10 days prior to the November meeting in order to make the December Faculty Senate cutoff for curriculum changes. It depends on the type of proposal submitted how long it will take to reach the Committee on Curricula and Courses and if there are any external approvals required. Program actions may take between 6 months and 2 years for full review (ACAF 2.00). Review the various levels of approval needed for various types of curricular actions. (/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/curriculum_services/approval_process/index.php)

user_input: Who should I contact if I have a correction for DegreeWorks?
retrieved_contexts: ["University of South Carolina System DegreeWorks Web Audits -- Production System If you have questions about how to use DegreeWorks please visit Self Service Carolina Help(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/advisor_toolbox/certification/training-index.php) and click the Staff/Advisors section and then DegreeWorks Information. If you have questions or concerns with the content of a student's DegreeWorks audit which you are unable to resolve, please contact the Registrar’s office for your campus, on behalf of yourself and the student. Generally speaking, students should not contact the Registrar directly, and should work through their Advisor. DegreeWorks is currently being offered as a helpful reference for advisors (and students on select campuses), but should not be taken as an official source of information. Please be aware of the following issues: Upper level undergraduate students who have been admitted to any USC campus for graduate school, law school, or medical school will not be presented with an audit of your undergraduate degree at this time. Certain academic history items may not be accurately reflected; this includes credits for Advanced Placement and International Baccalaureate courses (AP, IB), coursework transferred from another college/university, study abroad coursework, or courses taken on another USC campus. Any exceptions and course substitutions previously authorized by your advisor or department chair may not be accurately recorded in DegreeWorks. Please keep an eye out for these and contact your advisor to resolve these again. Students taking courses or pursuing a degree on more than one USC campus at the same time, may have a degree audit that is not entirely accurate or complete for either campus. If you are unable to login, you may contact the UTS Service Desk between the hours of 9:00 - 5:00, Monday-Friday (except holidays), at servicedesk@sc.edu or 803-777-1800. Please provide your University network username and a clear description of your login issue. UTS cannot provide support or answer questions about the content of audits; only Advisors or Registrar personnel are authorized to address such concerns. Instructions: please check the availability of your campus' DegreeWorks audit service. If available click the campus name to enter the system. Campus Available?
