user_input: Do online students have to provide immunization records?
retrieved_contexts: ['it to the Graduate School. What should I do if I have an immunization hold? If you have an immunization hold, you should check the information on the Health Requirements(https://www.sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/graduate_school/new_students/health_requirements/index.php) page to make sure you have submitted all required documents. You can also contact the Immunization office from a link on the Health Requirements page. It is always easiest to submit immunization records even if you are in a fully online program because once the immunization hold is lifted it is not reset if you have submitted your immunization records. Students in on-campus or hybrid programs must submit immunization records. If you are in a fully online program, you are eligible to submit the Distance Learner Exemption Form, but you will have to submit it each semester to avoid having an immunization hold. If you have submitted your immunization paperwork and it has been 72 hours since submission, send a secure message in the myhealthspace system to the Allergy, Immunization and Travel Clinic Provider (AIT Provider) to ask that your immunization hold be lifted. You can also check to see if you have received a secure message from the Health Center in myhealthspace. I need to take some time off from my program. What should I do? Students may need to pause in their graduate studies for various reasons. If you do need to take a break at the end of a semester or before a new semester starts, it’s always a good idea to let your faculty advisor know via email and to notify Gamecock EdQuarters at COESTUDY@mailbox.sc.edu about your plans. If you have already applied for financial aid, you will want to check with the Financial Aid office to let them know you do not plan to continue by emailing uscfaid@sc.edu or calling 803-777-8134. If you are ready to return and have missed a Fall or Spring semester, you will', 'Submit Your Immunization Records & TB Test - International Student and Scholar Support | University of South Carolina Skip to Content International Student and Scholar Support SC.edu About Offices and Divisions International Student and Scholar Support New Student Arrival Submit Your Immunization Records Submit Your Immunization Records & TB Test Just like getting an I-20 and attending orientation, providing required immunization records is one of the steps you must complete before you can take classes at USC. Make sure you are prepared for this before you arrive on campus! What you need to know If you will live on campus(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/housing/index.php) , you must submit your immunization records to move in to your residence hall. All students , regardless of where you will live, must submit their immunization records to register for classes. If you are concerned that you will not be able to complete the immunization requirements before you arrive on campus, don\'t worry! University Health Services(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/health_services/) will allow you to take care of your immunizations once you arrive at USC. If you decide to get your immunizations done at USC, make sure that your health insurance is active before getting the immunizations done. What you need to do Navigate to the "Medical Clearances" portion of sc.edu/myhealthspace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_directory.aspx) . Click on "Immunizations Record" and attach supporting documentation signed by a medical provider before orientation. (Note: You can take a photo of your documentation with your phone and upload the photo). Enter your immunization dates and vaccine types in the "Medical Clearances" portion for each vaccine received. You can read more about required immunizations on the University Health Services website(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student-health-well-being/medical-services/immunizations/index.php) . Note that if you are from a country that is considered "high burden" for tuberculosis, you will need to complete a TB test and chest x-ray upon arrival to the U.S. Immunization Hold A registration hold(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/student_advising_resources/registration_holds/index.php) is on your account until your vaccination records are updated. Student Health and Well-Being\'s Immunization Office lifts these holds. University Health Services: Center for Health & Well-Being Immunization Office Phone : 803-777-9511 Fax : 803-777-3955 First Floor(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student-health-well-being/about/location/index.php) Room 104 1401 Devine St. Columbia, SC 29208 Hours Monday-Friday 8:30 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', 'Clearing Immunization Holds - Academic Advising | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Academic Advising SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Academic Advising Student Advising Resources Registration Holds Clearing Immunization Holds Clearing Immunization Holds The University of South Carolina (USC) immunization requirements are consistent with the recommendations of the American College Health Association and the Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. Compliance with all immunization, post screening tests, treatment regimens, and monitoring is Mandatory. Students not fulfilling the immunization requirements, with exceptions for valid medical contraindications or documented religious reasons, will not be permitted to register for or drop classes. Expand all Which immunizations are required? Student Health Services lists required immunizations on the Immunizations website. When are immunizations holds placed on students accounts? All students enrolled at USC will initially have an immunization hold on their account. The hold is removed when students are marked "Compliant" for required vaccines and the TB Screen Risk Form. How do students obtain a copy of their immunization records? Transfer students will need to request their immunization records from their previous school. Please note, SHS is not able to request records on behalf of the student. Students can contact their high school or primary health provider or pediatrician. SC residents can contact DHEC. Residents from other states, can contact their local health department. How do students enter vaccine information? Students will log into sc.edu/MyHealthSpace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) . Click on Medical Clearances from the menu Click on Update to enter the immunization information Students will enter the name of the vaccine and the date(s) received and then click on done. If the student chooses the incorrect vaccine, the staff at SHS can correct it. How do students upload immunization records? Students will need to upload a copy of their immunization record. This is required in order for SHS staff to verify the vaccines/dates entered by the student are correct. After the student clicks ‘update’ next to immunization record, a box will open with an option to upload documents. What happens when requirements are met? Once the student has provided the necessary records, or signed the distance learner form (for on-line students only & must be completed each semester) their name will appear on an immunization clearance list. Immunizations staff update the student\'s records and the immunizations hold is lifted in Self Service Carolina at midnight. Are there exemptions? You can only be exempt from fulfilling immunization requirements if: You have a permanent medical contraindication. You have conflicting religious beliefs. You are enrolled in only distance education courses. You will need to provide proof of your exemption status. Contact Student Health Services for more information. 803-777-9511 Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', 'official transcripts to our Office of Admissions at admissions@uscsumter.edu . If you would like to confirm if these have been received, call or text Admissions at 803-408-7814. 9. Provide Proof of Your Immunizations If you haven\'t uploaded your immunization information, please upload your immunization data to MyHealthSpace(https://myhealthspace.ushs.sc.edu/login_dualauthentication.aspx) . View a step-by-step tutorial about uploading your immunization information(https://www.sc.edu/about/system_and_campuses/salkehatchie/apply/new_student_orientation/my_health_space_tutorial.pdf) Watch a short video about uploading your immunization information(https://youtu.be/S7liZmSHAPM) 10. Activate Your Student Email Know your Network Username(https://myaccount.sc.edu/iam/) and password. Click on "Update Account Settings". Once you\'re logged in, you will see your Network Username under the Home tab. Your password for your email will be the same as your SSC login. Know your email address – networkusername@email.sc.edu To access your email through Office 365 and the Outlook Web App, go to outlook.com/email.sc.edu(https://outlook.office365.com/mail/inbox) . Login with your email and SSC password. KEY FEATURES: 50 GB of storage Includes ability to download Word, Excel, PowerPoint and Outlook Windows users can also download Access, OneNote and Publisher Spam and malware protection Install Office 365 on up to five computers and five mobile devices 11. Answer: Yes, online students do have to provide immunization records. However, they can submit the Distance Learner Exemption Form instead of submitting their immunization records each semester. But, if they choose to get their immunizations done at USC, they must ensure their health insurance is active before getting the immunizations done.
reference: Online students must provide immunization records or complete the Distant Learner Waiver. Visit sc.edu/myhealthspace to complete any immunization requirements or complete the Distant Learner Waiver. To complete the waiver: Log into https://sc.edu/myhealthspaceSelect Downloadable Forms (left side of the screen)Click on the Download button for your applicable formFill out the form and save to your deviceClick on UploadUpload the documentClick Save at the bottom of the pageNote that this waiver must be submitted each semester of enrollment. If you do not provide immunization records or submit the waiver each semester,you will receive an immunization hold and will be unable to register for courses. For help with an immunization hold,please contact Student Health Services at 803-777-3175.

LibKey Nomad isn't showing that the e-book is available. How can I check if the e-book is accessible through the library? Publisher sites and platforms represent the discovery starting points but do not represent the coverage of content which extends to *all* e-Books within a libraries collection! Search for the book title in the Find It @ USC search box on the library homepage. Find It @ USC will let you know if the book is available in an e-book or print format. Can’t find the book you’re looking for? Search Find It @ USC and use the PASCAL Delivers(https://pascal-usc.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/search?vid=01PASCAL_USCCOL:USC&lang=en&mode=advanced&search_scope=NewDiscoveryNetwork) option available in the Advanced Search. This will let you know if the book is available at another academic library in South Carolina. If the book is not available from another South Carolina academic library, you can request the book using Interlibrary Loan(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/find_services/interlibrary_loan/index.php) . Where can I view LibKey Nomad's privacy policy? Libkey Nomad is provided by Third Iron. response:
To access the library's online resources, there are several options available for both on and off-campus users. 

If you're on campus, simply visit the library website and start searching for articles, books, or other resources directly. However, if you're off-campus, you will need to use your network username and password to access these resources.

For a specific library database, first go to the University Libraries' FAQ page (<https://sc.edu/libraries/faqs.php>) and find the "How do I access a specific library database?" section. Here, you'll learn how to locate the database you need and log in with your credentials.

If you encounter any issues, don't hesitate to contact the library's support for assistance (<https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/ask_a_librarian/index.php>). They're always ready to help!
reference: Students can start at the library’s homepage to access subscription databases,online journals and ebooks away from campus using their network username and password. Learn more about Off-Campus Access to library resources,including book delivery and scans of print materials. Check out this online guide to accessing and discovering online resources for help getting started.

user_input: How can I get help with doing research?
retrieved_contexts: ['Get Started - Undergraduate Research | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Undergraduate Research SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Undergraduate Research Get Started Get Started OUR can help you narrow down your research project ideas, find the perfect mentor, make sense of funding opportunities, and do just about anything else you need to do to get started in research. Ready to Get Started? No project? No mentor? No problem! Step 1: Find a faculty research mentor - Let us help! We have options: Expand all What is a research mentor? The role of a mentor is to: assist in the development and articulation of a project idea and plan. help you understand the methods and concepts of research and scholarship within your field. guide and train you in the skills and/or techniques needed to complete a project. There is no pressure to come up with your own idea because most students work directly on a faculty project. Options for finding a research mentor Expand all View our Getting Started in Research Workshop Video Located in the Getting Started in Research Toolkit(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/getting_started_toolkit/index.php) , this video is designed to help students navigate the undergraduate research process. Resources and tips for finding your research interests and a mentor These worksheets are used in our Getting Started in Research Consultations and can help you clarify your research interests and also outline the research journey - start to finish. What are your research interests? The research journey : How to get involved, find a faculty mentor, and next steps. Tips and hints for emailing faculty about research opportunities Need an email signature? Check out the USC Email Signature Generator(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/communications/toolbox/resources/email_signature_generator/index.php) . Use our searchable research database(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/undergraduate_research/get-started/faculty_research_database/index.php) to identify faculty who have research interests similar to yours. Still have questions? Schedule a research consultation The Office of Undergraduate Research offers individual consultations where we will explore your research interests, walk through how to find and reach out to potential faculty mentors, and discuss next steps. To schedule a RESEARCH CONSULTATION* : Consultations will be held either in person or virtually through Teams video conferencing. If you select a virtual consultation, a weblink will be provided to you in your meeting confirmation email. Please click on the weblink at your designated meeting time to start your appointment. => Log on to sc.campus.eab.com => Click on "Make an Appointment" tab (right hand side of the screen) => Under what type of appointment, select "Involvement and Engagement" => Under service, select "Undergraduate Research Appointment" => Then click on the button "Find Available Time" Please feel free to include comments about where you are in the research journey (curious', "preregistration and how to preregister your research plan with Open Science Framework. Register online here(https://libcal.library.sc.edu/event/10065226) . New service seeking volunteers to support research The Office of the Vice President for Research encourages anyone who is interested to sign up as a volunteer on ResearchMatch. ResearchMatch(https://www.researchmatch.org/?rm=USC-V1) brings together people who are trying to find research studies and researchers who are looking for people to participate in their health-related studies. The program makes it easy for researchers to connect with volunteers and further their research projects. Anyone can register with ResearchMatch, including healthy volunteers, and signing up is easy! Visit the ResearchMatch website(https://www.researchmatch.org/?rm=USC-V1) for more information and to register. Register now for University Libraries research workshops Each semester, University Libraries hosts a variety of workshops for members of the USC community on research-related topics, including research data management, digital publishing and text analysis. Over the next week, University Libraries will host two workshops: Engaging Your Students through Experiential Learning in an Open Setting and the Graduate Student Research Toolbox. The workshops will take place virtually and the event URL for each workshop will be sent via registration confirmation email. Visit the University Libraries workshops page(https://libcal.library.sc.edu/calendar/workshops?cid=16861&t=g&d=0000-00-00&cal=16861&inc=0) to learn more and sign up for these exciting workshops. Sign Up for Research News Get the Weekly Research Update delivered to your inbox. * Required fields If you see this don't fill out this input box. Name: * Email address: * What would you like to receive? Research Newsletter Breakthrough Magazine Online Both Newsletter & Magazine Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits."]
response: To get help with doing research at the University of South Carolina, check out the "Get Started" section on the Undergraduate Research website (SC.edu). Here, you can find resources and tips for narrowing down your research project ideas, making sense of funding opportunities, and connecting with a faculty research mentor. You may also want to view the Getting Started in Research video or use the research interest worksheet in the Getting Started in Research Toolkit to clarify your research interests and outline the research journey from start to finish. Additionally, consider scheduling a research consultation with the Office of Undergraduate Research for personalized assistance. They can help you explore your research interests, find and contact potential faculty mentors, and discuss next steps.
reference: Online help is available through live chat,virtual Book a Librarian research appointments,email,and online guides and tutorials. See all the ways you can get research help from the library.

user_input: Do I need to get a library card?
retrieved_contexts: ['out this online guide to accessing and discovering online resources(https://guides.library.sc.edu/access-and-discovery) for help getting started. How can I get help with doing research? Online help is available through live chat, virtual Book a Librarian research appointments, email, and online guides and tutorials. See all the ways you can get research help(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/university_libraries/get_research_help/index.php) from the library. Do I need to get a library card? Your CarolinaCard is your library card, but you can still use the library if you have never been to campus to get a CarolinaCard. All enrolled students are set up with an online library account(https://pascal-usc.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/account?vid=01PASCAL_USCCOL:USC) that you can use to request and renew materials, see due dates and pin favorite materials to personal lists. Your login is your network username and password. This is also the login to access library databases, online journals, and ebooks. Billing/Fees Expand all When are my tuition and fees due? Tuition deadlines are set by the Bursar’s Office. You are responsible for monitoring important dates(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/bursar/my_bill/important_dates/index.php) and paying your tuition bill on time. Failure to pay your bill on time may result in being dropped from your classes. Who do I ask if I have a question about a bill? Questions about your bill should be submitted to the Bursar’s Office prior to the fee payment deadline through their contact form , or in person during normal business hours at 1244 Blossom Street Columbia, SC 29208; or via phone at 803-777-4233. How do I re-enroll in a course from which I have been dropped? If you are within the registration dates of the term for your course, you may register and pay the tuition and fees for the course using the Self Services Carolina (SSC) Program(https://ssb.onecarolina.sc.edu/BANP/twbkwbis.P_GenMenu?name=homepage) . If you have been dropped for non-payment of tuition fees and the registration dates have passed, you may contact the Instructor for approval to continue in the course. If your request is approved, you will then need to complete the Registrar’s Registration Exception']
response: As an enrolled student at the University of South Carolina, your CarolinaCard serves as your library card. However, if you haven't visited campus to obtain a CarolinaCard, you can still access library resources with your network username and password. To manage your library account, log in to the online library system(https://pascal-usc.primo.exlibrisgroup.com/discovery/account?vid=01PASCAL_USCCOL:USC) using your credentials for requesting and renewing materials, checking due dates, and saving favorite items to personal lists.
reference: Your CarolinaCard is your library card,but you can still use the library if you have never been to campus to get a CarolinaCard. All enrolled students are set up with an online library account that you can use to request and renew materials,see due dates and pin favorite materials to personal lists. Your login is your network username and password. This is also the login to access library databases,online journals,and ebooks.

user_input: When are my tuition and fees due?
retrieved_contexts: ["Tuition and Fees | MUSC Skip to content Education Student Life Enrollment Management Bulletin Tuition and Fees Bulletin Request Program Information(https://redcap.musc.edu/surveys/?s=EFHN8PTNDWXLRFFN) Tuition and Fees 2024-2025 Tuition and Fees(https://education.musc.edu/students/enrollment/bulletin/tuition-and-fees/2024-to-2025) 2023-2024 Tuition and Fees(https://education.musc.edu/students/enrollment/bulletin/tuition-and-fees/2023-to-2024) Academic charges are established by the Board of Trustees. Circumstances beyond the control of the University may require adjustment of these published charges without notice. The Schedule of Academic Charges is published annually and is available in June. All fees are payable in advance of or at registration. Payment applies only to the semester of registration and will not be credited to another semester except in the case of students granted military leave. Registration is complete when all charges are paid. The application for admission fee is payable when the application is filed; the matriculation fee is payable at the time the applicant accepts in writing the university's offer of admission. Billing Information Statements of student accounts are made available approximately 30 days prior to the term start date. Students may view and print their bills online at Life at MUSC Obligation for Payment Failure to make timely payments to remove any indebtedness to the University when due is considered sufficient cause to withhold diploma or transcripts, to suspend all University services, including enrollment, and to assign the student's account to a collection agency. The University reserves the right to assess interest, finance charges, and/or late fees on any indebtedness and all attorney's fees, collection agent cost, and other related cost and charges for the collection of any amount not paid when due. It is the policy of MUSC that a student's tuition account will be assessed an insufficient funds (NSF) fee for returned checks. The student will be notified by the University Bursar's Office explaining this situation. Should this situation cause tuition and fees to be unpaid after the first official day of class, a late fee will apply. Additionally, the Office of Student Accounts will place a tuition hold on the student's account until all tuition and fees are paid. Penalty will not be levied against financial aid recipients if the student can show that he/she was not responsible for the delay in the award. Methods of Payment ONLINE - Electronic Check: TouchNet - No Fee! - Pay online directly from your checking or savings account through TouchNet. Posts immediately - always confirm your payment posted to your statement through your Student Life Portal. Credit and Debit Cards (Online Only): American Express, Discover, MasterCard, Visa The convenience fee for credit/debit card transaction is 2.5% of the total payment amount. This fee will be added to your payment amount. MUSC does NOT accept in-person credit/debit card payments for tuition and fees** All credit card payments must be made online on Self-Service Menu at http://life.musc.edu(http://life.musc.edu) . Check payments- Mail checks made payable to MUSC to: MUSC Bursar's Office 1 S Park Cir, Bldg 1, Ste 402 Charleston, SC 29407 College Savings Plan (529 Payments) - It's easy to request a distribution from your account and have it electronically deposited into your bank account. From there, you can pay the school (or reimburse yourself) for qualified expenses paid out of pocket. You can also send payments directly to MUSC, if you prefer. SCTPP - account owner will need to submit a copy of their South Carolina Tuition Prepayment Program (SCTPP) card to studacct@musc.edu in order to verify & and prepare the invoice for submission. user_input: How do I re-enroll in a course from which I have been dropped?
retrieved_contexts: ["Click on the Student tab then the Registration tile. Click Register for Classes and choose the term from which you want to withdraw. Registered classes are listed in the summary window in the lower right corner. Each should have an action drop down list. When the drop down is clicked, a student can select the 'Drop/Withdrawal Course/W' option. Please note: if the WF period has begun, the option would read 'Drop/Withdrawal Course/WF'. Click submit to complete the action. If you are not able to withdraw, it is possible that there is a hold on your account. Go back to the home screen, and click the 'Registration Notices and Holds' option to view holds or notices on your account. Contact the department(s) listed to have the hold removed. Once you are no longer enrolled in courses and all financial ties to the institution are taken care of, you are considered withdrawn. Please note that students typically do not become inactive until they miss a major semester (fall/spring) without a record of enrollment. If you are still receiving communication, please contact the department listed on the communication or unsubscribe from the listserv if given the option. Leaving or Transferring from USC If you are leaving USC after a full semester, follow the steps below: Don’t register for courses for the next semester. Speak with the Office of Financial Aid and Scholarships(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/financial_aid/index.php) if you receive scholarships, loans, or grants and you plan to attend USC in the near future. Resolve any financial debt or other obligations with campus departments (Housing, etc). If you are an international student, please contact International Student Services at 803-777-7461. Many transfer questions can be answered by the admissions office at your new school for transfer guidelines (including financial aid). You can obtain a copy of your USC transcript(http://my.sc.edu) via Self-Service Carolina. If you are leaving during a semester, please refer to the information above. If you are leaving USC but not transferring, the information above still applies. However, if you have additional questions, contact us at withdrawal@sc.edu . Please note: If you miss an entire semester, and wish to return, you will have to reapply to USC. Returning from Withdrawal If you miss", 'schedule adjustment when dropping a course. If you would like to drop a course, check with your teacher to find out the last date to drop without a WF (withdrew failing) appearing on your USCL transcript. Simply changing your class schedule at the high school does not drop you from the official class roll. If you are taking classes at your high school, you must notify your school counselor that you wish to drop the course and the counselor will notify the Dual Enrollment Coordinator in writing. If you are taking classes on the university’s campus, you will need to go to the Office of Admissions to complete a withdrawal form. Failure to follow these procedures may result in an “F” being placed on your permanent University record. Transfer of College Credits At the end of the course, credit earned by satisfactory completion of dual enrollment courses (usually an earned grade of “C” or higher) will transfer to public South Carolina institutions, provided that the course is included on the List of Transferable Courses in the Statewide Transfer and Articulation Policy.(https://www.sctrac.org/) If the course is not included on the above list, you are responsible for contacting the higher education institution to see if the course credit will be accepted. If you plan on attending a private institution in South Carolina or any public or private institutions outside of South Carolina, you are responsible for contacting the institution and obtaining written assurance that the dual enrollment course credit will apply toward your degree requirements. Transcripts At the end of the course, you can check your grade and request a transcript online. To request credit transfer to schools other than USC, a student must have an official transcript sent to that school’s records office. If you are applying to more than', 'corner). Double check to make sure the course has been added to your schedule. The status will go from “pending” to “registered” and highlighted green). How Do I Drop A Class? Dropping a course can have financial and academic consequences. Before you drop a course, watch this video(https://youtu.be/FmUVQ5QA3Ok) and meet with the following people/offices: Academic Advisor Financial Aid Business Office Drop a Class Follow the steps below or view the video(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OCdUW-xznhs) to learn how to drop a course. Log into sc.edu(https://my.sc.edu/) . Click on the Student tab at the top of the screen. Click on the Registration box (3rd box from left on top row). Click on Register for Classes (on the left-hand side, middle). A new page will load. Select the semester for which you are dropping a course. In the lower half window on the right, your courses will be listed. Click on the dropdown menu next to the course you want to drop. Select Drop/Withdraw . Click Submit . How Do I Change My Major? In order to change your major, please submit the online form . If there is a hold on your account(http://my.sc.edu) the change of major will not be processed. What is an Academic Coaching Hold? Students on academic probation are required to attend an academic coaching session. These sessions are meant to establish a plan for success. We will discuss your strengths, set goals, and review resources. Once the session is completed, the registration hold will be lifted on your account. Make your academic coaching appointment today ! How Do I Get My Books? USCL offers the First Day Complete (FDC) textbook program through our campus store, Barnes & Noble. Students are automatically enrolled* in FDC and textbooks charges are added to their bill at the rate of $25 per credit hour. Charges can be paid along with tuition and fees or by using financial aid. Students participating in the program should not purchase required materials or pay outside sources for access to their materials. Students can opt-out of the program and purchase their textbooks individually from the Barnes & Noble store. For more information, visit the Bookstore – USC Lancaster | University of South Carolina . How Do I Pay My Bill? You can pay online through Self Service Carolina or in USC Lancaster Business Office. Business Office hours are 8:30 am - 5:00 pm Monday – Friday. response:
In order to re-enroll in a course from which you have been dropped, follow these steps:

1. Ensure the WF period has ended.
2. Go to the home screen and click on the 'Registration Notices and Holds' option to view any holds or notices on your account.
3. Contact the department(s) listed to have the hold removed.
4. Make sure you are no longer enrolled in any courses and have taken care of all financial ties to the institution.
5. Attempt to re-enroll in the desired semester.
6. If you encounter issues, contact the department offering the course for assistance.
reference: If you are within the registration dates of the term for your course,you may register and pay the tuition and fees for the course using the Self Services Carolina (SSC) Program. If you have been dropped for non-payment of tuition fees and the registration dates have passed,you may contact the Instructor for approval to continue in the course.  If your request is approved,you will then need to complete the Registrar’s Registration Exception Form. Please be sure to follow the instructions on the form and obtain all required signatures.

user_input: How do I get the Student Health Fee waived if I’m in an online program and do not attend courses on campus?
retrieved_contexts: ['If your request is approved, you will then need to complete the Registrar’s Registration Exception Form(https://dynamicforms.ngwebsolutions.com/casAuthentication.ashx?InstID=abef1d20-7cf9-4537-9149-b3df24e1e772&targetUrl=https://dynamicforms.ngwebsolutions.com/ShowForm.aspx?RequestedDynamicFormTemplate=57bcc39e-8aa0-49a2-a8f8-adafc1c630ef) . Please be sure to follow the instructions on the form and obtain all required signatures. How do I get the Student Health Fee waived if I’m in an online program and do not attend courses on campus? If you are enrolled in an online degree program and the Health Center Fee is not waived, contact the Health Center to request the waiver and then work with your department to provide the required information for a waiver for the fee. Technology Services Expand all How do I access Blackboard? Information about accessing Blackboard may be found here . Students can receive 24/7 Blackboard support by calling the IT Service Desk at 803-777-1800 or submitting a service ticket at sc.edu/ithelp . How do I get assistance for technical issues? Submit a request online through the Self-Service Portal(https://scprod.service-now.com/sp) Search the online Knowledge Base(https://scprod.service-now.com/sp) Chat(https://scprod.service-now.com/sp) online with a Service Desk technician. Available Monday-Friday, 9:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m.. Testing Expand all How are online exams administered? The course instructor determines how exams are administered and you should consult the course syllabus for information about exams. Are all online tests proctored? No, not all online tests are proctored. Is there a cost associated with a proctored online test? Yes, if your exam is protected by ProctorU. You will be required to pay an $8-14 fee for online proctoring, depending on the length of the exam, directly to ProctorU. Contact ODL If you have a question not covered on this page, please contact ODL at DLQuest@mailbox.sc.edu . Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', "show as pending until the university 'locks' you in around September 15 for Fall, and early February for Spring. Am I eligible to receive the health insurance subsidy? Full-time PhD* students and students hired as Graduate Assistants are eligible for the health insurance subsidy. Refer to the Health Insurance Subsidy page for more information. *Due to budgetary concerns, non-PhD doctoral students are not eligible for the subsidy unless hired as graduate assistants. I’m taking all web-based courses. Am I required to have insurance? If your program is formally identified as being fully online, the mandatory insurance requirement is automatically waived. (Students enrolled in a fully online program have a Distance Education concentration showing on their my.sc.edu(https://my.sc.edu) profile.) Which Z-Status students need to voluntarily enroll in the student health insurance? Who does not? Students meeting all criteria listed below need to voluntarily enroll through the Z-Status portal on the AHP website: US Citizen enrolling in 1-5 credit hours approved for Z-Status for the current semester not hired as a graduate assistant want the insurance coverage Notes: International students do not need to enroll voluntarily. You are automatically set up with the mandatory insurance. However, you will need to respond to the link in the AHP notification email to either accept or waive out of the coverage. Graduate Assistants whose hire has been fully approved through the HR process will automatically receive the mandatory insurance. You do not need to voluntarily enroll in the plan; however, you will need to respond to the link in the AHP notification email to either accept or waive out of the coverage. (Note the exception for US Citizens in fully online programs) Who can waive out of the mandatory Student Health Insurance Plan? While insurance coverage is mandatory for most graduate students, anyone who is covered under another insurance plan may waive/opt out of the University Student Health Insurance", 'insurance. Students with private insurance may waive out of the University-offered plan. Additional information is available from Student Health Services(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student-health-well-being/index.php) . How can I waive the health insurance charge (Proof of Health Insurance fee)? Instructions for waiving the health insurance fee are available on the Student Health Services(https://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student-health-well-being/insurance-fees/required-health-insurance/waiving-out.php) website. Which office do I contact for more information? Each office is responsible for the charges they load. Please visit the following links for more information about USC Columbia charges. Parking Services(http://www.sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/parking/) , Student Health Center(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student_health_services/index.php) , Housing(http://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/housing/) , and Office of Student Conduct and Academic Integrity . Additional information is available on the Bursar’s website Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', 'deans, recognizing the potential impact of healthcare debt and/or disability on a student\'s career if the student becomes seriously ill or injured, made insurance a condition of enrollment. MUSC is committed to providing the highest quality health care to students. Our team of medical experts will work with you to enhance your health and well-being and ultimately, help you achieve your personal and academic goals. Will I be charged for Student Health Insurance? Yes. MUSC has a hard waiver requirement. Each semester the insurance charge is added to the accounts of all eligible MUSC students. To be eligible, a student must be enrolled in 6 or more hours and in a degree seeking program. However, if you have creditable insurance coverage from another source, you can complete the online waiver process before the deadline (each semester). Once your waiver information is verified and approved, the insurance charge will be removed from your account. Important: A completed, verified and approved WAIVER is required each semester for students who do not wish to participate in the school sponsored Student Health Insurance Plan. Upon completion of the waiver form, a student will automatically receive an email notifying him/her of a pending waiver. How much does the Student Health Plan cost? The rates vary slightly year to year. Why is the spring premium higher than the fall premium? The fall premium covers August 1-December 31 or 153 days (42% of the year). The spring/summer premium covers January 1 - July 31 or 212 days (58% of the year). Do I need to complete any enrollment forms to enroll in the Student Health Plan? Yes, you need to enroll through the Academic Health Plans website before the coverage period begins to ensure benefits are activated on the first date of the coverage period. Because health insurance is required at MUSC, you will be automatically enrolled and charged if you do not enroll or waive by the deadline given each semester. Waiting for the automatic enrollment process to occur will delay access to benefits. What is meant by a "hard waiver"? A hard waiver program is one where students must be enrolled in an external verified/approved health insurance plan or in the Student Health Insurance Plan. Each semester, students are required and encouraged to review their enrollment status for the Student Health Insurance Plan. Students have the option of submitting a waiver if the student has coverage from another source and that coverage meets certain criteria. What if I am already covered by insurance and I am charged? During the enrollment/waiver period, students who have adequate health insurance coverage through a parent, spouse, or an individual plan, can waive out of the health insurance requirement by providing proof of insurance coverage in a comparable health insurance plan through the online waiver system. If the student does not waive out of the sponsored plan by the deadline date each semester, he/she will be automatically enrolled in the MUSC Student Health Insurance Plan and billed through Student Accounting. What are MUSC\'s requirements for alternate insurance coverage that would qualify for a waiver? Alternate health insurance plans are reviewed to determine if a plan is comparable to MUSC’s Student Health Insurance Plan. MUSC has identified the following criteria are to be applied in making this determination: Coverage must be effective on or before January 1 (spring) or May 1 (new summer students only) or August 1 (fall) and extend through the semester including breaks and holidays Coverage must be ACA compliant and allow the insured student to receive services in South Carolina (note – these are requirements for all plans according to the Patient Protection Affordable Care Act; online students physically located outside of South Carolina during the semester may be granted an exception if all other criteria are met) See Full List(https://musc.myahpcare.com/waiver) What are the requirements for International Students? In addition to the coverage requirements listed for all students (see #8 above), international students must have Global Emergency Services coverage that includes a combined benefit of US $50,000 for medical evacuation and repatriation of remains (for international students). For convenience, International students with insurance plans from other sources that meet all the requirements except for the minimum Global Emergency Services (GES) coverage may purchase just GES coverage through the waiver and enrollment online system. The University-sponsored Student Health Insurance Plan through Blue Cross Blue Shield of South Carolina meets all additional insurance requirements for international students and dependents. How do I submit a waiver? Waivers can only be processed online and only during the specified dates. You will need the following information to complete the waiver: Student ID (PVID) number Name and Address of the insurance company Policy holder’s name (main person’s name owning the plan) Policy / Member ID number Group number Policy holder’s zip code (the billing address zip code) Insurance Company’s customer service telephone number Copy of the front and back of your insurance card How will I know when the insurance charge is removed from my account? Each semester the insurance charge is automatically added to the accounts of']
response: If you are enrolled in an online degree program and the Health Center Fee is not waived, you can contact the Health Center to request a waiver for the fee. Then, work with your department to provide the required information for the waiver. More information about accessing Blackboard, getting assistance for technical issues, and submitting a service ticket can be found on the IT Service Desk's website. Online exams are administered based on the course instructor's discretion, so consult the course syllabus for details. Not all online tests are proctored, and if your exam is protected by ProctorU, you will be required to pay an $8-14 fee for online proctoring, depending on the exam length. For questions not covered on this page, contact ODL at DLQuest@mailbox.sc.edu.
reference: If you are enrolled in an online degree program and the Health Center Fee is not waived,contact the Health Center to request the waiver and then work with your department to provide the required information for a waiver for the fee.

reference: Information about accessing Blackboard may be found here. Students can receive 24/7 Blackboard support by calling the IT Service Desk at 803-777-1800 or submitting a service ticket at sc.edu/ithelp.

user_input: How do I get assistance for technical issues?
retrieved_contexts: ["IT Resources for New Students - Division of Information Technology | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Division of Information Technology SC.edu Division of Information Technology About News 2020 News Archive IT Resources for New Students IT Resources for New Students Technology Resources for Incoming Students Welcome to UofSC! The Division of Information Technology (DoIT) offers technology support and assistance during your years as a UofSC student. Here are some helpful resources: How Can We Help? Technology Support Available The DoIT Service Desk is your single point of contact for computer, technology and IT-related questions and support. Here are the ways you can get support: Submit a request online through our Self-Service Portal . Search the online Knowledge Base for instructional articles that help you troubleshoot technology issues on your own, at any time of day. Chat online with a Service Desk technician. Available Monday-Friday, 9:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m. Call the Service Desk at 803-777-1800. Available Monday-Friday, 8 a.m.-6 p.m. Carolina Tech Zone The Carolina Tech Zone (CTZ) provides hands-on technology support for all students. Their services include connecting to the network, installing software, diagnosing computer problems, removing viruses, providing mobile support and more. The CTZ is open Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. – 6 p.m. during the fall and spring semesters and is located at 901 Sumter St., Suite 119, right beside the Gamecock iHub(https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/hrsm/for_the_community/gamecock-ihub/index.php) . *The CTZ will resume operations when campus reopens. Social Media Follow us on Twitter ( https://twitter.com/UofSCtech(https://twitter.com/UofSCtech) ) and Facebook ( https://facebook.com/UofSCTech(https://facebook.com/UofSCTech) ) for IT updates, outages and news! Computer Resources Computer Information and Discounts: A computer is highly recommended, but not required. We support Macs, Windows, and Linux. If you bring it, we can support it. Apple and Dell offer student discounts on computer purchases . To get education pricing at Apple, visit the Gamecock IHub(https://sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/hrsm/for_the_community/gamecock-ihub/index.php) , located at 901 Sumter St., Suite 123. The iHub is an Apple Authorized Campus Store serving USC students, faculty and staff members, and alumni. In addition, Gamecock iHub offers in-house product repair and services of personal Apple computers. The services are provided by Apple-authorized service technicians from the university's Division of Information Technology. At this time, the Gamecock iHub service team is not able to repair or service iOS devices such as iPhones and iPads. When purchasing a computer from Dell(http://www.dell.com/usc) , go to the university’s membership page at Dell(http://www.dell.com/usc) . Free Microsoft Office 365 Microsoft Office 365(https://scprod.service-now.com/sp?id=kb_article&sys_id=6afd311813184780b6c0b9722244b0e8) is available for free for as long as you are a student at the university. It includes the latest versions of Word, Excel, PowerPoint, Outlook, OneNote and more for both Mac and Windows. You can install Office 365 on up to five computers and five mobile devices. Also included is OneDrive, an online file service that provides you with 50GB of free cloud storage to store your documents and access them from any device, anywhere. More information and download instructions are available in the Knowledge Base(https://scprod.service-now.com/kb_view.do?sysparm_article=KB0010233) . Software and Antivirus The DoIT offers a variety of software to students, faculty, staff through the university’s agreements with vendors for both personal and university purchase. Most software is available at discounted rates or, in some cases, the software is free. Students can visit the Software section of my.sc.edu(https://my.sc.edu) to see available selections or take a trip to the CTZ for assistance with downloading software. Students must have current antivirus software installed and activated and all critical operating system updates completed on your computer before you can connect it to the campus network. Antivirus software is included with Microsoft Windows. Visit Carolina Tech Zone if you need assistance with installing antivirus software. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits."]
response:
To get assistance for technical issues at the University of South Carolina, there are several resources available to you. Firstly, you can submit a request online through the Division of Information Technology's Self-Service Portal, where you can find instructional articles to help troubleshoot technology issues on your own at any time of day. Alternatively, you can chat online with a Service Desk technician from Monday to Friday, 9:30 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. You may also call the Service Desk at 803-777-1800, which is available from Monday to Friday, 8 a.m. to 6 p.m.

Another resource is the Carolina Tech Zone (CTZ), offering hands-on technology support for all students, including connecting to the network, installing software, diagnosing computer problems, removing viruses, and providing mobile support. The CTZ is open Monday-Friday, 8 a.m. – 6 p.m. during the fall and spring semesters and is located at 901 Sumter St., Suite 119.

Lastly, follow the Division of Information Technology on Twitter (@UofSCtech) and Facebook (@UofSCTech) for IT updates, outages, and news.
reference: Submit a request online through the Self-Service PortalSearch the online Knowledge BaseChat online with a Service Desk technician. Available Monday-Friday,9:30 a.m.-4:30 p.m..

user_input: How are online exams administered?
retrieved_contexts: ['they can use on their exam. Proctor the exam by walking around the room to prevent cheating behaviors. For online exams: Create a practice exam for students to feel comfortable with the online testing environment. Both via e-mail and through exam instructions provide tips for how to create an effective testing environment at home. Consider shifting from several high stakes exams to shorter more frequent exams. Change test questions to be more applications based to require more variety in how a student responds. This makes it also harder to Google for answers. Consider use of Respondus monitor and/or Respondus lockdown browser. During an exam Make a verbal announcement to the entire class regarding any negative behavior you are observing. Approach the student(s) directly. Speaking in a low tone and describe the behavior you are seeing and ask them to refrain. You can also ask them to give you any unpermitted materials until the exam is over. If you suspect cheating, you can take their current exam, move them to another seat or take away any materials and then give them a blank copy of the exam so they may finish. For online exams: Send an email to all students notifying that you have a concern cheating is occurring. State the specific behavior that is happening and let them know this will be addressed. After an Exam Review the concerning exam(s), outline the students behaviors and document what led you to believe the student cheated through our online report form(https://cm.maxient.com/reportingform.php?UnivofSouthCarolina&layout_id=2) . Consider discussing the concern with the student (privately) and let them know you are required to report the concern to the Office of Student Conduct and Academic Integrity. Wait to provide a grade or grade penalty until the student has completed the academic integrity process. Adapted from "Confronting']
response: Online exams at the University of South Carolina are typically administered using a proctored environment. To ensure a fair testing experience, instructors may create a practice exam for students to familiarize themselves with the online testing platform. They also provide tips for setting up an effective testing environment at home. Instead of relying on high-stakes exams, they might shift to shorter, more frequent exams with various question types to make it harder for students to look up answers on the internet. Some instructors use tools like Respondus Monitor and/or Respondus LockDown Browser to secure the testing environment. In case of suspected cheating, they make a verbal announcement to the whole class about observed behaviors and address the issue privately with the student(s) involved. If necessary, they may ask the student to relinquish unpermitted materials and continue the exam on a blank copy. For follow-up, they send an email to all students stating concerns and let them know about potential cheating consequences. After the exam, they review the concerning exams, outline the suspicious behaviors, and document the incident through the Office of Student Conduct and Academic Integrity report form. Grades or penalties are not imposed until the student completes the academic integrity process.
reference: The course instructor determines how exams are administered and you should consult the course syllabus for information about exams.

user_input: Are all online tests proctored?
retrieved_contexts: ['Test Proctoring - Distributed Learning | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Distributed Learning SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Distributed Learning Test Proctoring Test Proctoring Three Flexible Options The Office of Distributed Learning provides test proctoring services for blended and online courses. Access administrative support and test proctoring options for paper and computer formats. Testing Center — Columbia Campus Students may take proctored exams in the Office of Distributed Learning Testing Center on the Columbia Campus. The center, which is located at 1716 College Street(https://www.sc.edu/visit/map/index.php?id=744#!m/223362) , has 9 computers/testing workstations. The center is open Monday – Friday from 9:00 a.m. – 5:00 p.m. Online Test Proctoring There are two options for online test proctoring: Expand all Monitor, by Respondus Monitor provides automated exam proctoring and enables students to take assessments within Blackboard. After a one-time installation of a plugin, each student follows a startup sequence that guides them through completion of requirements set by the instructor (these requirements are entered when you set up your assessment in Blackboard). Monitor records each student’s session for later review and applies monitoring algorithms to notify instructors of the timestamp of any suspicious activity for their review. This product is integrated in Blackboard, and available for use at no cost to students, instructors, or academic departments. System Requirements: Windows: 10 (but not 10S), 8, 7; Mac: OS X 10.12 or higher; or iOS: 10.0+ (iPad only). Students must also have a web camera (internal or external) & microphone and a broadband internet connection Expand all Quick Start Guide for Faculty Blackboard(https://web.respondus.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/RLDB-QSG-Bb-Instructor.pdf) and Blackboard Ultra(https://web.respondus.com/qsg-bbultra-instructor) Quick Start Guide for Students Blackboard(https://web.respondus.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/08/RLDB-Quick-Start-Guide-Bb-Student.pdf) and Blackboard Ultra(https://web.respondus.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/RLDB-Quick-Start-Guide-BbUltra-Student.pdf) An overview for your students (Video) Introduction to Respondus LockDown Browser for Students(https://web.respondus.com/lockdownbrowser-student-video/) (video: 2 minutes) Recommended', 'a proctor from any accredited college or university that offers testing services. Most institutions have testing facilities or testing services offered through their online program. You will need to complete a Proctor Request Form [pdf] for approval to take an exam at an off-campus testing location. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', "that instructors share instructions with students if they choose to use Respondus. Respondus Monitor is available for unlimited use and there is no charge to students to use the service. ProctorU allows students to take exams at times and locations that are convenient to them. ProctorU's services are accessed using a computer equipped with a webcam and internet connection, ProctorU verifies the student's identity, records the testing session, and has every testing session reviewed by a certified proctor to ensure integrity. An $8-14 fee for online proctoring, depending on the length of the exam, is paid by students directly to ProctorU during their exam. Instructors wishing to register an exam in ProctorU should contact Shannon Carson in the Office of Distributed Learning at scarson@mailbox.sc.edu . ProctorU resources including guides for faculty and students as well as recommended language to include in the syllabus to inform students of the test proctoring fee can be found on the Office of Distributed Learning Test Proctoring(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/distributed_learning/test_proctoring/index.php) page. Be aware that not all students have access to a webcam and the University does not have the ability to provide this technology. Are there final exam considerations for students with disabilities? You should have received accommodation letters for students with disabilities who are enrolled in your course(s). Be sure to review the accommodation letters if you are providing an online exam. The most commonly used accommodation is extra time on exams. Be flexible. The length of time a student sits and views a computer screen", 'ProctorU Available for All Courses Beginning in Spring 2020 - Distributed Learning | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Distributed Learning SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Distributed Learning About News 2020 News Archive ProctorU Available for All Courses Beginning in Spring 2020 ProctorU Available for All Courses Beginning in Spring 2020 The University of South Carolina awarded a contract to ProctorU in 2017 for remote online test proctoring as a result of an RFP process. ProctorU’s service is currently being offered to those teaching blended and online courses. However, beginning with the Spring 2020 semester, individuals teaching courses through any modality (traditional/face-to-face (F2F), blended, or online) may use ProctorU’s service. Cost of Using ProctorU ProctorU’s fee model includes a fee per test which ranges from $8.00 to $14.00 based on the length of the test. Students use a credit card to pay this fee directly to ProctorU when registering for the test proctoring. Please noted that if a student is taking a blended or online course, the faculty can work with the Office of Distributed Learning to provide free test proctoring at ODL’s testing center. Due to space constraints, this monitoring is not available for those teaching traditional/Face-to-face courses at this time. Benefits and Best Practices for Using ProctorU ProctorU’s service has many benefits including providing a secure environment to identify potential academic integrity violations during the online test taking timeframe and allowing students the flexibility to take tests at various times as determined by the faculty/instructor. Additional benefits of using ProctorU include Live proctor, multi-factor identify verification of test-taker using photo ID and option to enable knowledge based challenge questions. Live technical support available before and during exam. Timeline view of proctoring events including full session recording of webcam and computer/exam activity, and any suspected academic integrity incidents. LTI integration with Blackboard. Additional information about and resources for those using ProctorU can be found on the Office of Distributed Learning’s test proctoring page. If you would like use ProctorU, please contact Shannon Carson at scarson@mailbox.sc.edu or call 803-777-2189. Challenge the conventional. Create the exceptional. No Limits.', "during the exam. Students and faculty have significant privacy concerns(https://www.gettingsmart.com/2020/07/respondus-lockdown-is-this-the-answer-to-prevent-students-cheating-on-exams/) about third-party recorded remote proctoring. Students have reported that they find remote proctoring systems relatively easy to circumvent, and online resources provide ways to bypass these systems(https://jakebinstein.com/blog/on-knuckle-scanners-and-cheating-how-to-bypass-proctortrack/) . (from: Rutgers University , Remote Exams and Assessments: Tips for Exams and Alternative Assessments(https://sasoue.rutgers.edu/teaching-learning/remote-exams-assessment#special-advice-for-open-book-assessment-in-quantitative-courses)) ) If you choose to use these systems, you can help your students use them successfully by doing the following: The Practice Test The single most important thing you can do to help your students be successful in taking their test with Respondus Monitor is to give them a practice test several days before their first real test. This requires students to download the necessary software and test their computer hardware and internet connection in a low-stakes environment. If they encounter problems, they can work with the Office of Distributed Learning , DoIT, and/or Respondus support to clear up any issues before they take a real test. In addition, the practice test will familiarize the students with the environment and the procedures for taking the test, and that will lessen any anxiety students might have about the experience. Give Them Tips and Guidance to Help Ensure the Process Runs More Smoothly These can be included in the syllabus or provided as a resource handout. Avoid wearing baseball caps or hats that extend beyond the forehead. If using a notebook computer, place it on a firm surface like a desk or table, not your lap. If the webcam is built into the screen, avoid making screen adjustments after the exam starts. A common mistake is to push the screen back, resulting in only the top portion of the face being recorded. Don't lie down on a couch or bed while taking an exam. There is a greater chance you'll move out of the"]
response: Not all online tests are proctored, but the University of South Carolina offers test proctoring services for blended and online courses. There are two options for online test proctoring: Respondus Monitor and ProctorU. Respondus Monitor provides automated exam proctoring, while ProctorU allows students to take exams at times and locations that are convenient to them, with a certified proctor reviewing the testing session to ensure integrity. Students can also use a proctor from any accredited college or university offering testing services. For more information, visit the Office of Distributed Learning Test Proctoring page.
reference: No,not all online tests are proctored.

Some universities and colleges have testing facilities or testing services offered through their online programs, which might not require a separate proctoring fee. It is essential to check with the specific institution regarding their policy.
reference: Yes,if your exam is protected by ProctorU. You will be required to pay an $8-14 fee for online proctoring,depending on the length of the exam,directly to ProctorU.

user_input: Where do I go for advisement inquiries,such as turning in academic forms,obtaining a dean’s signature,and taking care of academic conflicts?
retrieved_contexts: ['Frequently Asked Questions - My Arts and Sciences | University of South Carolina Skip to Content My Arts and Sciences SC.edu Study Colleges and Schools My Arts and Sciences Undergraduate Students Advising For Students Frequently Asked Questions Frequently Asked Questions Where do I go for advisement inquiries, such as turning in academic forms, obtaining a dean’s signature, and taking care of academic conflicts? The Office of Undergraduate Studies, located in Flinn Hall, Room 110, manages academic procedures and conflicts. Flinn Hall is located on the Historic Horseshoe, directly behind the War Memorial on the corner of Pendleton Street and Sumter Street. To contact this office, please call 803-777-2993. If you need a form signed by the dean, please submit it online at go.sc.edu/CASforms(https://go.sc.edu/CASforms) . How do I change my major? To change your major within the College of Arts and Sciences visit the Office of Undergraduate Studies or make an exploratory advising appointment with the University Advising Center(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/changing_majors/index.php) . Some majors have special admission requirements and procedures; ask your major change advisor about these requirements. If you want to change to a major in another college or school of the university, you must make an exploratory advising appointment with the University Advising Center(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/changing_majors/index.php) to learn about eligibility, requirements, and major change procedures. To make an appointment with the Office of Undergraduate Studies: email CASundergrad@mailbox.sc.edu or call 803-777-2993. To make an exploratory advising appointment with the University Advising Center: visit sc.campus.eab.com(https://sc.campus.eab.com/login?prevent_redirect=true%22%20\\t%20%22_blank) or call 803-777-1222. How do I find the name of my advisor? If you are a freshman, you are assigned to a first-year advisor who advised you at summer orientation. The first-year advisor will contact you via email when it is time for advisement. If you are a sophomore, junior or senior, your advisor is assigned by your major department. It is your responsibility to contact your major department to find this information and arrange for your advisement. How do I get an override into a class that is already full? Closed courses and those requiring special permission require an override, which can only be granted by the department. Contact the department(https://www.sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/artsandsciences/internal/undergrad_students/advisors_ugrad_directors.php) offering the course to request an override. After receiving an override or special']
response: The Office of Undergraduate Studies, located in Flinn Hall, Room 110, manages academic procedures and conflicts. Flinn Hall is situated on the Historic Horseshoe, directly behind the War Memorial on the corner of Pendleton Street and Sumter Street. To contact this office, please call 803-777-2993. If you need a form signed by the dean, please submit it online at go.sc.edu/CASforms(https://go.sc.edu/CASforms) .

user_input: How do I change my major?
retrieved_contexts: ['to follow up with the department. Please refer to the Override/Seat Notification Requests(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/student_advising_resources/registration_resources/override_seat_notification/index.php) webpage for more information. How do I change my major? If you wish to change your major, you will need to schedule an appointment(http://sc.campus.eab.com/) with the Exploratory Advising team(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/changing_majors/index.php) . Each major has its own set of GPA and/or credit hour requirements that you must meet to change your major. See if you meet requirements for a new major, view upcoming change of major deadlines, and familiarize yourself with how to change your major using the Change of Major Requirements Table(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/advising/changing_majors/major_requirements/index.php) . When do I register for classes? Where would I find my registration time ticket? To find your registration appointment time, go to Self Service Carolina(https://ssb.onecarolina.sc.edu/BANP/twbkwbis.P_GenMenu?name=homepage) and login. Click on the "Student" button and select the "Registration" box. You must be advised prior to registration. You will not be cleared to register for courses until you are advised. Can I take courses at another institution? What do I need to do? You may take up to eighteen (18) semester hours of courses in transient status provided that (1) you are in good standing, (2) a Special Enrollment Request(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/registrar/documents/special-enrollment-request.pdf) form must be approved in advance by your academic advisor and assistant dean, and (3) the other institution is fully accredited and the course work meets University specifications for transfer credits. Transient work must be passed with a grade of C or higher. Other restrictions may apply, you will need to clarify with your advisor. Does the department offer scholarships? Yes, the department offers undergraduate awards yearly for continuing students. Please check the website for scholarship information and applications.(https://web.qa.sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/artsandsciences/internal/undergrad_students/scholarships/index.php) What do I need to do if I am missing classes due to either a documented illness or family emergency? Contact the Office of Student Advocacy(https://sc.edu/about/offices_and_divisions/student_affairs/our_initiatives/academic_success/ombuds_services/index.php) in the Office of Student Affairs and Academic Support at (803) 777-4872 or studentadvocacy@sc.edu . I need a form signed by the Department Chair. How can I get that signature? Please follow up with your academic advisor. It is best to send an email with the document needing signed attached. I need a form signed by the Dean. How can I get that signature? Please submit the document to the College of Arts and Sciences Forms Portal . Other Commonly Used Resources College of Arts and', 'Advisor may be subject to a $15 no show fee. Attend Major Change Drop-Ins If you already know the major you want to declare, consider dropping in for a 15 minute appointment. During this appointment an Exploratory Advisor can: answer general advisement questions show you how your prior coursework fits into your new major provide supplemental advisement for your new major Changing majors within your college or school? How you change major within your current college or school depends upon which college or school you’re in. If you want to change majors within the College of Arts and Sciences you may make an appointment with an Exploratory Advisor(http://sc.campus.eab.com/) or visit the Office of Undergraduate Studies in Flinn Hall.(https://www.sc.edu/study/colleges_schools/artsandsciences/about/contact-us/location.php) If you want to change majors within the College of Information and Communications you may make an appointment with an Exploratory Advisor(http://sc.campus.eab.com/) or visit your current CIC advisor. If you want to change majors and you are in a college or school other than the College of Arts and Sciences or the College of Information and Communications, simply meet with your assigned academic advisor for next steps on switching your major. Major Change Resources Expand all Change of Major Directory The Change of Major Directory provides program information, GPA requirements, and necessary "how to" steps for changing majors into each of the 11 colleges/schools on the Columbia campus. View the Change of Major Requirements Table. Undergraduate Academic Bulletin Learn more about academic programs offered at USC and their requirements in the Undergraduate Academic Bulletin(http://bulletin.sc.edu) . Alternate Pathways to Nursing If you are a current nursing student, and/or are considering a major in a related healthcare field, watch these videos to learn more about alternative major pathways that can lead to similar career opportunities in health care. Exercise Science Parallel Plan(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mhqI53YTsxo) Public Health Parallel Plan(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LU7bXiEBmDM) Cardiovascular Technology Parallel Plan(https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tjcp55G1ZjQ) Drop-In Advising Hours 1 to 4 p.m. Exploratory Advisors are available for in person drop-in advising sessions Monday-Thursday from 1 to 4 p.m. To attend a drop-in advising appointment, check in at the front desk (Close Hipp, Suite 381). An Exploratory Advisor will see you to you as soon as possible. Students will be advised on a first come, first served basis. If students are unable', 'Changing Majors (Office of Exploratory Advising & Academic Coaching) - Academic Advising | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Academic Advising SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Academic Advising Changing Majors Changing Majors (Office of Exploratory Advising & Academic Coaching) Considering a change in your major or switching your college or school at USC? Investigate next steps with help from our Exploratory Advising team. Our advisors can help you explore degree options, evaluate requirements, or help you prepare for an academic advising session. Areas of Interest Areas of Interest are groups of individual majors that fall under a larger academic umbrella. Each Area of Interest brings together degree programs that appeal to common interests, use (and teach) similar skill sets, and lead to related career paths. Exploring Areas of Interest can help you match your unique talents and interests with specific degree programs, discover USC’s 90+ majors, and make connections between your studies and career possibilities. Change of Major Requirements Each major has its own set of GPA and/or credit hour requirements that you must meet in order to change your major. See if you meet requirements for a new major, view upcoming change of major deadlines, and familiarize yourself with how to change your major using the Change of Major Requirements Table . Need help navigating the Change of Major Requirements Table? Schedule an appointment with an Exploratory Advisor! Make An Appointment(http://sc.campus.eab.com) Exploratory Advisors can help answer a variety of questions about switching majors on the Columbia campus. Schedule an appointment if you would like to explore different major options, see how your prior coursework fits into your new major, need supplemental advisement for your intended major, or need help figuring out how to change your major. (See below if you are interested in changing majors within your current college or school.) Please note: Students who schedule and miss an appointment with an Exploratory Advisor may be subject to a $15 no', 'advisor. You will need to meet with your advisor during the advisement period in the Fall and Spring Semesters to discuss your current courses and to plan for future semesters. You will not be allowed to register for courses until you have been advised. Feel free to meet with your advisor at other times if you have questions or are having problems. If you do not know who your advisor is, send an e-mail to the Undergraduate Director. Changing Major to Statistics Note that students transferring to USC from another institution or wishing to change their major to statistics must complete either MATH 141 or STAT 515 with a grade of B or better before being allowed to declare a major in statistics. If you are interested in changing your major to statistics or adding a statistics major, please send an e-mail to the Undergraduate Director. Senior Check Early in your next to last semester, you should meet with your advisor to complete a major program card. This card lists the courses you have taken or will take to complete your major and cognate (or minor) requirements. After completing the major program card, call the College of Arts and Sciences Undergraduate Office (777-2505) to schedule a Senior Check Appointment. You will need to take the major program card to your Senior Check Appointment. The Senior Check verifies the remaining course requirements needed for graduation. Double Majors and Minors It is possible to major in statistics and and to have a second major or a minor in many other fields at USC. A second major or a minor replaces the cognate requirement for the B.S. in Statistics degree. Students considering a second major or a minor should make their advisor aware of this fact as soon as possible. For double majors, all degree requirements for each major must be satisfied. (Only one of STAT 509 or STAT 515 may be used for major or minor credit.) There is a substantial overlap between Statistics general (pre-major) requirements and requirements for Mathematics', "Change of Major Requirements - Academic Advising | University of South Carolina Skip to Content Academic Advising SC.edu About Offices and Divisions Academic Advising Changing Majors Change of Major Requirements Change of Major Requirements If you're considering or planning a change of major within USC, investigate the requirements of your new college or school, the process you'll need to go through to make the change, deadlines and other relevant details.
